reviewText:
So I finally hit the mark where I got my monies worth.

Now the real question is, Was it worth it?"

That's honestly a hard question to ask. Because there was a time where I got bored with it after like 8 hours and stopped touching it then I suddenly went back to it for another 50+ hours.

Now. Was it fun? Hmm...I'd say yes. I did indeed have some fun with the game which is way I was able to play through the full story.

Unfortunetely that was one of the reasons it fell short for me.  The story was really quite weak. It was a pretty generic chosen one affair.

Some optional bosses gave me a feeling of challenge as you could juggle them pretty well but they could be monsterously hard hitters. Knocking my allies and me down with a single hit half of the time meaning that I had to get very
date:
very comfortable with the defence and dodging mechanics which made beating them feel like an actual challenge and made victory all the sweeter.

Unfortunetely I can't say the same for the story bosses. At all. In comparison they were expremely weak.

But those low points didn't hurt it enough  for me to not enjoy it enough to play.

But it does stop me from recommending it at full price.

If you get it on sale
recommended: go for it. It's a fun little thing\n\nOh! And for a final word I did REALLY enjoy a good number of the characters. Many are a bit forgetable (Especially Sorey sadly) But Edna
hoursPlayed: Lialah and even Zavid are an enjoyable bunch."

reviewText:
I really enjoyed this, and it has been a great introduction into the 'Tales' series for me.

I can't comment on how it compares to the others, I can't comment on what it 'could have' been.
All I can say is it is a fantastic JRPG in it's own right and should be treated as such.

The Characters are likeable, even the bad guys. The gameplay is solid, and lets you slowly ramp up the difficulty by playing the highest available for a certain amount of time, until you find your sweet spot.

You can even turn it into practically a visual novel hybrid, as you can set the game to auto-play battles with suprising efficiency, so you can sit back and watch the action and enjoy the anime-esque banter.

reviewText:
WORKAROUND FOR LANGUAGE CRASH ON STARTUP AND AUDIO ISSUES

There is a bug in the game that may cause a crash when using a surround sound setup.

If you have Razer Surround, try disabling that and run the game again.

For surround headphone users, if you have a USB connector that you plug your headset into, try plugging your headset into a 3.5mm audio jack instead. (The round green one)

If you have speakers and headphones, try setting your default audio device to your speakers instead of your headphones.

If character voices do not play, set the ingame audio setting to stereo instead of surround.

If your audio is distorted or crackling, you can try to set your speaker audio frequency to 16 bit, 48000 Khz, DVD Quality by opening the sound settings on your computer, select the speakers you use, right click and select properties, and under the advanced tab, there should be an option to change speaker frequency.

Overall, Tales of Zesteria is a great JRPG and a great first Tales game to be released on Steam.

Runs well on lower end systems and is well optimized. Runs at a stable 30 FPS at max settings and 1080p on a i7 4710HQ and a GT 840M.

reviewText:
I've been a huge fan of Tales Series. I'm very glad to see it come to the PC platform.

The game runs pretty smooth (although there are some minor things like the USB headset startup crash and the screen tearing that can be fixed from turning on Vsync from the nvidia/amd panel). The music and story seems fantastic as always. Voice actors are pretty good. This is a hell of an RPG game. If you're a fan of Action RPG/JPRG-anime, boy you're in for a treat. You're gonna love this one! 100% satisfaction guaranteed I assure you.

All in all, fantastic game - 1000/10

reviewText:
Man I love this game. I can never put down my controller. This is also my first time playing a game in the series, BTW.

Pros:
- Great controller support
- Funny/cute scripts now and then
- Anime cutscenes now and then. Ufotable strikes again
- Unique battle system. It's actually really fun and more then button smashing, once you get used to it.
- I really like how you can play as characters other then the main character. And how you can switch characters in the middle of battle.
- I love every single character, they all have distinct personalities.

Cons:
- The English VA is kinda meh, but this isn't new in localizations. The lines are pretty awkward. Good thing there's a japanese option, but the problem is the subtitles follow the English lines which are slightly different.
- Camera angles get awkward during battles at times
- The CPU AI's make me want to cry sometimes.

For a 2015 game I expect better graphics but it's pretty good considering it's anime style.

reviewText:
How to review a game that gave me so many mixed feelings about it's quality?  This is a tough one.  This is a solid RPG no doubt, with some really interesting characters, and decent combat.  But in no way does this game compare to some of the Tales games that came before it.  Here are the Tales games I beat prior to this:

Tales of Legendia
Tales of Symphonia
Tales of Vesperia
Tales of Graces F

So what are the issues?  Let's start with the camera angle in battles.  This can be absolutely annoying sometimes because you might not even be able to see Sorey or anything at all.  Second the final boss, phase 2, seems a lot on the cheap side, and warrants the cheap way you're going to beat him.  Also the dungeons are very basic, the puzzles are non existent mostly.  Lastly the story is weak.  I mean there's elements that are interesting, but where other Tales games really excel at story telling, this one is pretty plain.

I still recommend.  It's a good game, but not a great game.

reviewText:
Where to begin? This game has quite a bit of content, still only on my second playthrough. Between leveling lords of the land, improving my relationship with shop and innkeepers I'm kept pretty busy, let's not forget the insanity chaos mode brings. While the game is interesting plotwise the first time around it can get repetitive on a second run, well even the first run can too, since you get abilities later in game to help you overcome obstacles in older dungeons, even backtracking in quite a few cases.

That being said theres plenty to keep you busy, I personally loved the skits (especially Edna and Meebo) the fusion system is a bit tricky to grasp at first but you can find guides online, (Also fixes for things like the 30 fps lock) I can't be bothered to do that myself though.

The only things I'm inconvienced by are the camera angles sometimes in dungeons, and the fact I have to see tutorial messages after my second playthrough. other than that I have quite a blast with Sorey the demon lord and his demonically dressed minions Seraph friends. I love the fashion system.





couple of tips if you get this

- use free & free under battle options so you can move around any direction during a fight.

- before you do new game+ get lords of the land as high as you can, typically 3-4k grade wise on the ng+ page to get all
the glorious boons for your second playthrough. It's a huge difference.

- don't throw away the 10 damage/armor joke items, You can carry them over when you sanctify with boons.

- There is a Alisha DLC after you beat the game. Along with a bonus dungeon before the final boss only appears after game completion.


This game is probably best to pick up on a sale, although I don't regret purchasing it at full price, my first tales game but a great experience. (except for the damn water trial) I hate that one oh so much.

reviewText: If you're a Tales fan, then why are you even hesitating to buy it? I don't fully get the negative reviews for this game. This game has some pretty good humour, both from skits and ingame happenings. That's something that I don't see that much in any other Tales game I played before. The battle system is great, as you can switch out characters during battle. Previously you would likely choose your 4 favourite characters and left the rest to rot in the party, now you can use all of them swiftly, so no obsolete characters. The characters are what I expect them to be, the weapon system is also a nice addition to the game. Overal, I think it's a great game. And for a PC port, it does pretty well.

reviewText:
Just finished this, went through almost everything pre-game, not yet done poostgame or DLC. It is a good solid game although I would have liked to wait for it to go down in price, I don't think it is worth a new game price.

I have played a few of the Tales games, although by no means all of them, and I enjoy the series. This game mostly lived up to its name, although it feels like it is diverging a little from its original formula. It feels a lot darker and more political than the others, although all Tales games have an edge to them. There is a lot more running around collecting things and backtracking, some of which can get repetitive, where the others have felt a lot more linear up until the end. However, it is still as epic and story driven as the others. The music is okay but some of it felt too ambient and subtle, where I prefer more traditional JRPG music (a problem I also had with Graces at times). The battle system is mostly the same sort of thing but felt a little more awkward than the previous games. Strangely, I found this game easier to control with a keyboard and mouse than a gamepad, despite it being from a long line of console RPGs. The button mashing feels smoother with a mouse. Then again, the series is slowly changing anyway and at least they kept a lot of the important things, like the Katz!

reviewText:
Well... Where should I start first?
This game, Tales of Zestiria, was definitely one of the weakest titles I've played so far.
I expected it to be all improved and much more ways to explore the Tales world, but I'm afraid that's not It.

The characters were all nice and all, but the lack of skits, which we all know that plays a major part in every Tales game, killed everything in me. I loved the designes of the environment, characters, etc. and not getting to take a closer look at them made me incredibly sad. This is one big mistake this time.
The combat was pretty easy, yeah (for me at least), but that has never troubled me. There are different game difficulties, after all. It was a new kind of gameplay and I actually enjoyed it quite a lot. It was very interesting and lovely.

The story was fine but there was a big portion of missing parts and we all wanted to know about it. The ending of Zestiria was just??? (more like Tales of Guess(tiria)...

And the biggest thing i dislike is when they try to recycle areas on every Tales game. Tales of Graces F reminds me so damn much of Zestiria, holy cows!

But anyway... If you are a big fan of Tales titles and you feel the need to conquer every possible Tales out there... Just DO IT!!!
It's not that bad as people may think it is. It's totally fine and nice, but nothing spectacular and big. Relax and enjoy~!

reviewText:
Excellent game to sate your JRPG needs
As this was my first 'Tales of' game, I was pleasantly surprised at what I got myself into. Being a JRPG fan, I was afraid the game would be too short or have other types of limitations. Quickly finding myself proven otherwise, I was really stoked at what the game had in store.

+ Overall a great PC port. Very much playable with keyboard and mouse, though I use my 360 controller out of preference.
+ A decent storyline that is not too overly complicated to follow. It's nothing spectacular or groundbreaking, though it was engaging enough to keep me playing.
+ The characters are also really good, maybe somewhat static at times but I enjoyed them. They were what made the story keep flowing as well as it did. The interactions between them are really nice as well.
+ A pleasant cell shaded artstyle that's quite easy on the eyes. Personally, I really loved it as the anime fan I am. Some places look really good, and I loved exploring caves and forests alike.
+ An astonishing soundtrack. Sometimes, I found myself walking around without doing much progress just to listen to the music. That's not to speak about the trial dungeons, which I find to be exceptional. The OP too. Just remember to patch in the version with vocals.
+ Solid gameplay, the combat is superb and rightly so as it's what made the game for me. However, the combat might not be for everyone. Look up some gameplay of it.
+ Good replayability due to the skill system, I'll probably play through the game again on some higher difficulty to try some different options, but I don't think that's necessary to get the full experience.
+ It's... Very long. Over a hundred hours and I've yet to beat the game, though I assume that's because I'm a tortoise when it comes to gaming. It wouldn't surprise me if you could beat it in 50h or so, probably less.

- Camera in combat can be a bit clunky sometimes, especially in tight corridors.
- The open world" is somewhat lacking. You will find yourself running through empty large spaces quite often unless you want to spend money on fast travelling.
- Level design could've been better. They look good
date: but are quite linear and don’t give much room for exploration as the map is fully lit and shows you where to go.\n- Minor occasional framedrops during combat.\n- The skill system is really complex
recommended: especially the forging part of it and knowing which skill is better for each character etc. After so long of playing
hoursPlayed:
I'm still not completely sure how to properly craft the type of equipment I want.
- Prepare to be bombarded with seemingly endless amounts of tutorials.

To sum it up

reviewText:
+ High quality japanese voice acting with famous anime VAs.
+ One of the best english dubs in Tales series. (No high-pitched characters or particularly bad VA choices.)
+ Very good translation.
+ Lots of animated cutscenes.
- Serious camera issues in combat. I don't think I've ever been so ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off at camera in any game before.
- Overly complex equipment upgrade system. Even if you understand how it works it still requires way too much micromanagement and memorization.
- Situationally unaware companion AI. This can be especially annoying against bosses since many of them have one-shotting AoE attacks.
- Armatization(fusing with another character) simplifies your moveset so much that it takes all skill away from the game.
- The world isn't nearly as interesting as in previous Tales games. It's very dull and lacks atmosphere and memorable places.
- Side characters don't get almost any screen time and antagonists are easily the worst in the series.

Verdict: It's still better than Dawn of the New World and Xillia 2. If you're a Tales fan, get it. If you're new to the series, it's better to start with one of the other games.

reviewText:
After finishing the game I've decided to put in additional thoughts and provide the perspective of someone who hasn't played any other recent Tales games. I didn't expect a lot about the game and by all means I enjoyed it, some points in this review people might disagree since some of them expects a lot and so on. Nevertheless, here are my thoughts:

+Deep battle system, it does not encourage you to just mash buttons on your way to victory, which is true if you're playing in higher difficulties.
+Skits are very entertaining and always a thing I look forward to.
+Lots of character development among the main characters of the game and everyone is likeable in terms of personality. Some secondary characters also provided a huge part in the story.
+Difficulty system rewards you with better drops and allows you to learn the battle system much faster.
+There's still post game content once you've finished the game and lots of stuff gets unlocked once you start NG+
+The music of the game was spectacular, mostly the music inside the trials.

~ I'd stay neutral story-wise as it is a subjective matter on how you take the game, it feels lacking at some point on some characters but other than that it all made sense to me.

- Equipment system is too complex and grindy. If you want to maximize the potential of the system, you need to grind a lot and I find it hard to maximize everything in your first playthrough it would be better if you try to maximize it on subsequent playthroughs.
- Unless you're really good, some, if not most, battles forces you to use armatization since some monsters/bosses can kill your characters pretty easy. This happens most of the time on higher difficulties (Intense, Chaos) since the level of the enemies grow a lot and damage potential is increased.
- Armatization can be abused to the point a battle can be very cheap. i.e. spamming a seraphic arte over and over until the enemies die.
- Camera during battles becomes awkward when fighting in small corners as the camera gets zoomed in a lot to the point you can't see anything. A slight fix would be to use the Free Walk" button to be able to see your character.
- The AI of your allies doesn't really help you much in battle
recommended: they die a lot for no reason. I find this very frustrating on some boss fights
hoursPlayed: even on some random encounters
voteText: since they tend to target your allies a lot or cast huge spells which your allies just tank. They also tend to split from armatization then die immediately afterwards even if you try to armatize them. In order to alleviate this
helpfulPercent: you have to micromanage everyone during fights to minimize the deaths and hope that they don't mess up everytime you switch into another character.\n\nGreat overall game
votesHelpful: which you can play at your own pace (which I did)
votesTotal: I finished my first playthrough by finishing all the sidequests and doing what I can to improve my equipment."

reviewText:
First and foremost, I would like to say I am brand new to the Tales Of series in terms of playing the games, as Tales of Zestiria is the first game I actually have the proper platform for (PC). I guess that makes this a more or less unbiased review in terms of series nostalgia, which may make it more or less appealing depending on who is reading it.

I'll get straight to the point here -- this is my first ever review on Steam, and I am writing it exclusively to say that this game is amazing. Downright incredible. From the very start, it pulls you in with charming designs, likeable characters and interactions, and a battle system that feels unique, flexible, and interesting. And as you go along, this feeling never diminishes, even once. Steam doesn't seem to have clocked all of my hours since I played a good number of them offline, but I have been playing for a fairly good amount of time, and I am still marveling at the novelty of the characters, the exciting variety in the gameplay, and the beauty of the world built around everything this game has to offer.

If you enjoy action RPGs, I would say don't hesitate for even a second in picking up ToZ. If you enjoy story-driven games, DEFINITELY do not wait. ToZ is largely driven by a charming and engaging story which doesn't feel tedious or exhausting, largerly due to the characters it focuses on. If you like games purely for aesthetic reasons, you have a real charmer here, too, with exciting and gripping character and location designs.

In short: play Tales of Zestiria. It's wonderful, and you won't regret it.

reviewText:
If you're a Tales fan you should be getting just about what you expect. For anyone else, if you're looking for effective story moments with likeable characters, satisfying battle mechanics and a vast world full of content to explore without minding some cheese and repetition, then you'll enjoy this game. The story in the Tales franchise never comes down to black and white, and while Zestiria doesn't really shine in the plot or the character department as well as some other Tales games, it does have some genuinely touchy moments as well as humorous ones through its course in common Tales fashion. The artstyle is also clean and vibrant, and the animated cutscenes by Ufotable are pleasing to watch.

The battle mechanics are a positive trademark of the Tales franchise, focusing on fast, action based real time combat that revolves around evading attacks and locking the opponents into combos by exploiting their weaknesses. It's easy to get into and hard to master, starting out extremely simple and then giving you more and more to work with, although you can also simply transform into a different form and murder everything without that much thought. Battle mechanics have been done better in a couple other Tales games, but Zestiria is still good at creating a system where skill plays a considerable enough role and beating bosses doesn't always have to come down to more grinding. There are also 5 different difficulty settings to work with starting out with 3, with harder difficulties yielding better drops.

As for the equipment system, you have 5 equipment slots with every equipment having 4 skill slots, and there are a total of 50 skills in this game that you can stack or combine in specific ways to create bonus effects. You get the skills you want by fusing copies of the same gear together, but getting those copies of gear with the specific skills you want before the fusion process is based too heavily on RNG and ends up being way more trouble than it's worth, so for the most part you'll just end up ignoring this whole mechanic, and fortunately it isn't needed in any way to make progress even on harder difficulties. Still, it's an unsatisfying aspect that will hopefully be executed better in the future, as it is a neat idea.

The world is split into several open overworld sections, towns, dungeons and fight arenas, with unique discovery points, collectibles and optional boss monsters to find in each separate area. The fight arenas are an exception however, as they seem to be designed mostly for equipment grinding. While there's a vast number of optional dungeons, they can be quite repetitive as they're all very similar with each other. Most of the main story related dungeons are fine though unless you're specificaly looking for clever design or complex puzzles, as there won't be much of that here.

New Game+ system is something that the franchise likes to give attention to, letting you earn points called Grade on your playthrough that you can use to buy bonuses and special traits for your next playthrough. Zestiria game has a new approach to this, letting you acquire guardian spirits called Lords of the Land for each town which you can then level up through battle performance and by offering them items, and the Grade you get after your playthrough is based on their levels. This process also unlocks other advantages, making it an interesting system, although one confusing aspect about it is  that the points used for leveling up the spirits are also called Grade despite having nothing to do with the actual Grade you get for NG+ bonus purchases.

While Zestiria falls a bit short of where some other Tales games have set the bar, it's ultimately a good game if viewed as a standalone and as such I can recommend it to any RPG fan.

reviewText:
I'd rate this game 8/10

Graphics

Tales series has a more cartoon-ish/anime style as oppose to more realistic style, so you are not going to find high def textures like you would in Final Fantasy or dragon age. The animations, character details and anime cutscenes are great, and smooth even at 30fps, framerate shouldn't be a problem. There is room for improvement for the environmental objects though.

Story

Definitely not a strong point of this game. The story is quite plain and predictable, even though tales series games are usually more character-driven, they are just OK in this game. If you are not familiar with JRPG games you may find the story and/or characters unbearable even.

Gameplay

I finished the game (and ALL sidequests) in 70 hours. However if you would like to collect things and be a completionist you'd definitely need more than that. There are a lot of customization options for your characters, battles and more, very high replayability as expected from a Tales game.

reviewText:
Tales of Zestiria is Namco Bandai's first release of a Tales game on PC and the port is pretty solid. There's only a little bit of stuttering with maxed out settings. All-in-all it's a very good first port of a Tales series to PC. It follows the Tales formula of innocent youth facing a harsh world that was popularised in Tales of Symphonia and overcoming adversity with the power of friendship (though not Tales of Graces f FRIENDSHIP"). The characters are written very well and feel like they could be real people facing the struggles within the game.

Pros:
Constant frame rate in battle. There have been no dropped frames inside battles.
There is different AI patterns based off of difficulty. I noticed this when I was fighting a certain boss earlier in the game. His attack patterns were more stragetic in trying to stagger me instead of just trying to attack through my combos.
Humorous dialogue. A lot of the skits have been localised fairly well and feel like they keep the original tone.
Cons:
30 FPS lock. Before this review is obliterated by the dislike button hear me out. There's noticeable input lag when trying to do big combos during the game. There are times where a combo should have been fired off but it winds up not happening because the input was received on the wrong frame. It is jarring to have this happen repeatedly in a fight where you need to be able to stun-lock/combo-lock your opponent. I really do hope that Tales of Symphonia on PC is not just a direct port of the PS3 version which is similarly locked at 30 FPS.
Level pacing. This may just be me playing on Moderate/Hard on my first playthrough but there is a crushing level spike with every new area. Where most of the level spike can be off-put by mastering the dodge system and having a lot of Battle Skills active
date: the level spikes make it feel like grinding is the answer to a lot of the progression problems."

reviewText:
WARNING SPOILERS

Good game with enjoyable characters and fun yet tricky to master combat. On the downside the story was sort of all over the place and there was a serious lack in villians. Also I know the game is suppose to be about exploring ruins but come on every dungeon besides the trials looked the same and were a real bore to run through.

COMBAT

Combat was a big plus though; being able to switch in and out Seraphims, while switching between characters on the fly is a blast which allows you to takes control of all six characters in a single fight (though you do need to unlock the battle skills first). the AI is pretty wonky like most Tales of games making it so switching between Sorey and Rose using the block + directional buttons a must unless you like seeing Rose get 1 shot in every boss fight. You can easily save Seraphims by switching them out to dodge attacks. The only real negative points I would give to the combat is camera getting stuck on walls/invisable walls and all the invinciblily frames on bosses where you can't damage them making you wait for whatever animation they are doing to end. If they wanted to give the bosses some breathing room I would suggest an instant knockback move or something.

CHARACTERS

Characters were a lot of fun always joking around and throwing out puns left and right. I really enjoyed the group talking about each enemy they encountered. Even Alisha the princess knight who wasn't in the group very long was very likable to bad for her she lost her lead role to Rose an essentric assassin who is creeped out by supernatural stuff (for little while at least). It really is a insane group of characters, with Lailah spouting nonesense, Edna teasing Mikleo and Mikleo overreacting, Dezel talking to animals or giving facts about wildlife, or Zaveid... being Zaveid you'd think they'd give Sorey something to stand out more besides geeking out on ruins with Mikleo.

STORY

Story can get random, Sorey can't see Seraphims cuz Heldalf said so, and so the now invisible Seraphim to Sorey no longer help him because they don't like being ignored or they were tired idk, Rose was gonna get married (Haha what!?) and Dezel somehow causes the person she was gonna marry to turn into a hellion just because it adds drama, and how about Mikleo being a Seraphim? Did the last Shepherd kill his baby nephew or was it son? Wait did the last Shepherd marry his sister Muse? Guh I feel like they glanced over a lot of parts like that while saying, What was that? Plot holes? Pshh why fill those in when we could mold the dirt into forgetful boss fights!" Seriously would of liked to see more villians or at least the 3 villians they gave us more often... Come on crazy fox guy you see at the beggining then end
date: creepy girl is middle then end
recommended: I'm not even going to count Alisha's teacher Maltran as a villian cuz you see her like 2 times and suddenly she is a villian which you don't really care about cuz you've only seen her TWICE
hoursPlayed:
and Heldalf is always just standing around letting his purple stench spread all over while I guess he is thinking about what he is going to have for dinner? I'm not saying there weren't any good scenes between the cast and villians i'm just saying interacting with them more instead of a random hellion would of been nice.

Overall Pros/Cons

Pros:
-Characters
-Combat
-Japanese Audio
-Equipment System
-Music

Cons:
-Fox dude wtf is his deal?
-75% of dungeons look like the same ruin or cave with differen't colors
-Swimsuits as DLC (Whatever happened to there being hotsprings for this? I thought that was gonna be a thing... this time it was just a random skit...)
-Boss invincibility frames

Eh:
-Story had it's moments
-Open maps looked nice but I didn't exactly have fun trudging across them
-Sorey x Mikleo dat ending
-Alisha leaving kind of a bummer

reviewText:
i really enjoyed this game and i'm really happy to see tales on pc!

that being said, i don't know if this is something i'd recommend to a newcomer to the series. if this does end up being your entrypoint into the series, it's good to know that this game is quite unlike any tales game prior.

the story is really fun and interesting. it leans a bit on the cliched side, with the bulk of the story basically being a Chosen One situation, but the game focuses more on the people you meet rather than how wonderful and great you are for being the Chosen One. it delves into a lot of questions of morality and, although perhaps not exploring them as deeply as one would hope, it is still a very satisfying experience.

the combat is pretty good. for those familiar with tales of graces, you'll likely be rather familiar with the basics of this combat system. rather than having HP and TP (essentially magic power), you have HP and a Chain meter, which allows you to perform basic actions such as attacking, casting spells, using special attacks and dodging. this meter refills over time, and at a decent pace, so it's not frustrating or debilitating by any means. i'm just personally not a fan of replacing TP with something that recovers over time and also governs the use of regular attacks. that didn't really restrict me from enjoying the game, though. i really enjoyed it

something i don't like at all is the equipment skill system. every piece of equipment in the game starts out with one or more skills attached to it. by combining these skills with other skills, you can get a variety of other effects as a result. this sounds cool, and at first i thought it would be, but it gets annoying later on. the equipment fusing (and thus, skill fusing) system makes little to no sense and basically encourages desperately clinging on to old, worse equipment in the hopes that you find something with better skills. the worst case scenario for me was early in the game when i had a skill bonus that gave me +20 to all of my stats. this sounds great! but then any time i get a new piece of equipment, i can't equip it, because even if it raises one of my stats, it would cancel out the stat gain from the bonus skill. it's very confusing and i can't really do it justice in essay form, but i really did not like it. it was a nice idea, and i welcome experimentation, but i do hope this does not make a return in later games.

i also have to give this game a special credit for its use of music in cutscenes, boss fights, and dungeons. with the addition of go shiina as a composer, there were some extremely unexpected songs that really stood out amongst the usual sakuraba pieces that are in the game. that's not to say i dislike sakuraba's work by any means, but it's incredibly refreshing to hear another style in the game. what stood out for me the most is the music for the wind/water/fire trials and the music for the tiamat battle, which i won't go any further into here.

as i said though, there's a lot in this game that makes me very hesitant to recommend it to first time players of the tales series. it is very unconventional, and while that's often something i would applaud, i don't feel they were necessary changes. for instance, your HP is not tied to your level, but rather how many bosses or side bosses you've beaten. i didn't find this to be an issue personally, but i've heard a lot of people say it's not very fun for them. it's a personal thing, i suppose. the game also has a lot of wide open areas with a character whose top speed is a slight powerwalk. sure, there are skills to increase speed, but that's only for about 20 seconds after a fight, which can often be something you're not looking to get into when exploring a new area or walking through low level ones for the umpteenth time.

so if you're going into this game as an introduction to the series, keep in mind these changes. i highly recommend trying out another game in the series if you're on the brink of enjoying it but its oddities are holding you back. personally i would say try tales of vesperia or tales of symphonia (which will be released on steam in 2016!).

if you're experienced with tales games and you think the changes aren't bad or you just want to try and see for yourself then i absolutely recommend the game. this is by leaps and bounds the best looking tales game there ever has been, but there's so much more to it than just flashy graphics and breathtaking landscapes.

TL;DR it's a good game but be wary that it is somewhat unconventional

reviewText:
I am glad this game was released on PC.  Japanese games are always geared towards consoles, so the release of a PC game like this should be supported.

I dont know why the Tales Games are not as popular as the Final Fantasy series.  The combat is as good as it gets in RPGs is incredibly fun, you can get by with button mashing, but for higher difficulties, you need to know what your doing.

The plot is your typical JRPG stuff, a good vs. evil, wtf are they talking about, etc.    Characters and writing is very good.  Edna made me laugh on multiple occations.

Keyboard controls are a little awkward but customizable enough to make it work.  Control support is there and reccomended.

Its good, buy it, support it so more games like this will be released on PC.

reviewText: DEMON FANG
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Story

+ Well-written
+ Several climaxes
- At a certain point it gets a bit stretched
+ sometimes humorous

Sound/Music

+ Soundtrack is overall great
+ Some memorable tracks

Control/Gameplay

++ Great Battle System (Fusionic Chain Linear Motion Battle System); if you've played some of the Tales of games before, you will get into it faster; it's fun; fast-paced
- Battle System is beginner unfriendly (at least it took me a while, but the fun starts, when you grasp it)
~ In battles: the camera makes sometimes weird things but you can get out of it most of the time
+ Control with a controller or with keyboard+mouse is good.
~ World map is too big: You will spend some time running around. Some people like it. I don't. Thank God there are warp points.
+ Multiplayer (only in battles), but...
- ... the camera acts even more funny

Graphics (can't say much since I have to lower resolution etc. so my laptop can run this game)

+ Attacks/Techniques (called Artes) look very cool

Replayability

+ There is a New Game Plus: You can carry over some stuff and activate bonuses

Features/Other (minor) stuff worth mentioning

~ Weapon/Equipment Skill System: Every weapon/equipment can have up to four of 50 skills. Get better results by stacking or order them in a certain way. However, this takes time to do so and requires a little bit of farming. You don't have to rely on it too much on a regular playthrough.
~ Level System: For each level you gain - unlike other JRPG's - your stats increase only a little.
To get stronger you have to rely on good weapon/equipment.
+ Skits: There are a lot of them! And I like them, since they are funny or give more insight etc.
+ Post Game stuff
+ Some Optional stuff like optional bosses etc.
+ 5 Difficulty settings

Archievements

+ Most of them are not too hard to get
+ Made me play the game a second time on a higher difficulty
~ Some Missable archievements
- There is one archievement that relies too much on randomness

Conclusion

For fans of the Tales of series or/and JRPG this is a must-have.
For others I can recommend this game and it's worth picking up.

reviewText: This is my first Tales title from the long running Tales of series. By being new to the title, I had a lot of headaches and frustrations in coping to its over complicated battle system, annoying equipment fusion and skill system, but the innovation is real! Do not be fooled by its colorful graphics and anime style cinematics, because this is not your typical JRPG. I want to see more of the series here on steam, and I can't wait to get my hands on Tales of Berseria.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
i really enjoyed this game and i'm really happy to see tales on pc!

that being said, i don't know if this is something i'd recommend to a newcomer to the series. if this does end up being your entrypoint into the series, it's good to know that this game is quite unlike any tales game prior.

the story is really fun and interesting. it leans a bit on the cliched side, with the bulk of the story basically being a Chosen One situation, but the game focuses more on the people you meet rather than how wonderful and great you are for being the Chosen One. it delves into a lot of questions of morality and, although perhaps not exploring them as deeply as one would hope, it is still a very satisfying experience.

the combat is pretty good. for those familiar with tales of graces, you'll likely be rather familiar with the basics of this combat system. rather than having HP and TP (essentially magic power), you have HP and a Chain meter, which allows you to perform basic actions such as attacking, casting spells, using special attacks and dodging. this meter refills over time, and at a decent pace, so it's not frustrating or debilitating by any means. i'm just personally not a fan of replacing TP with something that recovers over time and also governs the use of regular attacks. that didn't really restrict me from enjoying the game, though. i really enjoyed it

something i don't like at all is the equipment skill system. every piece of equipment in the game starts out with one or more skills attached to it. by combining these skills with other skills, you can get a variety of other effects as a result. this sounds cool, and at first i thought it would be, but it gets annoying later on. the equipment fusing (and thus, skill fusing) system makes little to no sense and basically encourages desperately clinging on to old, worse equipment in the hopes that you find something with better skills. the worst case scenario for me was early in the game when i had a skill bonus that gave me +20 to all of my stats. this sounds great! but then any time i get a new piece of equipment, i can't equip it, because even if it raises one of my stats, it would cancel out the stat gain from the bonus skill. it's very confusing and i can't really do it justice in essay form, but i really did not like it. it was a nice idea, and i welcome experimentation, but i do hope this does not make a return in later games.

i also have to give this game a special credit for its use of music in cutscenes, boss fights, and dungeons. with the addition of go shiina as a composer, there were some extremely unexpected songs that really stood out amongst the usual sakuraba pieces that are in the game. that's not to say i dislike sakuraba's work by any means, but it's incredibly refreshing to hear another style in the game. what stood out for me the most is the music for the wind/water/fire trials and the music for the tiamat battle, which i won't go any further into here.

as i said though, there's a lot in this game that makes me very hesitant to recommend it to first time players of the tales series. it is very unconventional, and while that's often something i would applaud, i don't feel they were necessary changes. for instance, your HP is not tied to your level, but rather how many bosses or side bosses you've beaten. i didn't find this to be an issue personally, but i've heard a lot of people say it's not very fun for them. it's a personal thing, i suppose. the game also has a lot of wide open areas with a character whose top speed is a slight powerwalk. sure, there are skills to increase speed, but that's only for about 20 seconds after a fight, which can often be something you're not looking to get into when exploring a new area or walking through low level ones for the umpteenth time.

so if you're going into this game as an introduction to the series, keep in mind these changes. i highly recommend trying out another game in the series if you're on the brink of enjoying it but its oddities are holding you back. personally i would say try tales of vesperia or tales of symphonia (which will be released on steam in 2016!).

if you're experienced with tales games and you think the changes aren't bad or you just want to try and see for yourself then i absolutely recommend the game. this is by leaps and bounds the best looking tales game there ever has been, but there's so much more to it than just flashy graphics and breathtaking landscapes.

TL;DR it's a good game but be wary that it is somewhat unconventional

reviewText:
I don't commment much on games but I like this game. Since I've been playing for 3 days and put 20+ hrs into I can say these things:

Storyline 8/10
I hear alot of negatives about the story line. I don't get why they don't like it. I find the story pretty good. Of course alot of reviews are from those who have played the other gaems in the series. Since this is my firest time playing the Tales OF series and a JRPG type of game I guess I don't get what they mean. I give it 8/10 cuz at some points in the game I lost track of some of the story, of I'm still playing.

Combat 9/10
I like the combat system it reminds me of Quest 64. I give it 9/10 beacuase man, if you understand right away good for you. But for me, after 20hrs of gameplay I'm still just press random keys lol. You have to puit some time into learning the system to get the right combos and all that.

Graphics 10/10
I'm pretty much gonna have to say it, but it's nothing special but I give it 10/10 becasus the detail is nice, You can see pretty far away, and I like the animated look of the game. Just don't expect anything close to Fallout 4 graphics if you buy the game.

Anyway, I'd recommend it. I'll just say, the closest game that I've play that this game also reminds me of is FLYFF (Fly for Fun) which is also a great MMORPG and I'd recommend that too.

reviewText: Ok, Tales of Zestiria, I hardly have any say about this game as I have very few hours as of writing this review and I will likely update it as time goes on, but there are problems. Mainly with explaining mechanics and how you do things, for someone like me who does not own an Xbox controller and is just using a standard USB controller with a PS3 layout the button mappings are a complete mess and some don't work at all. Meanwhile it does not help that in some battles you get a kinda random tutorial and are required to do certain actions and sometimes pressing the button that should do that action does nothing at all. also while this could just be a problem of me not using an Xbox controller but sometimes it does not even tell me what button I should press on the controller to get the desired action and instead tells me what button on the keyboard to press, and during all this, you could be in a said tutorial battle-sequence thing where you can't quicksave nor access your control mappings.(From the little time I used mouse and keyboard, most of this is averted by using them, but who wants to play a JRPG with a keyboard and mouse!?) There is also a lack of settings, when you set your volume, you better be damn pleased with it, because as far as I can tell, there isn't a way to change it, but all that aside, I don't mind just figuring out stuff as I go along as I'll likely end up re-playing this game as time goes on and I get used to the battle mechanics, if you want clear tutorials, this game does not deliver. Speaking of battle mechanics, this game is a cross of Xenoblade Chronicles, and Kingdom Hearts (2 to be exact, there are even drive forms!) Unlike those games though, while this one does have a free roam ability during battles, it does not really offer any tactical advantage besides not being locked to a grid. Meanwhile the actual combat is a mix of KH and Xenoblade, there really is no good way to explain it, but pointing the left control stick or (WSAD respectively) and whatever you have attack set to will do a different attack, meanwhile dodges take up part of your combo, meaning if you dodge once and attack immediately after, you will do the second hit of your combo. On the story side of things, it's pretty normal, kid grows up in some strange circumstance/something that makes him different from the rest some interesting stuff happens in his normally uneventful life, baddies show up, and before you know it, you end up with some mystical power/ legendary role and get tasked with killing what I would presume to be the final boss. Holy ♥♥♥♥, that's one large wall of text, don't worry over time as I learn the game better and have more thoughts I'll format this and make it look nice, but for now, this is my opinon overall. It's worth it for 50% off, I would not have gotten it under any other circumstances, from what I have played it is not worth 40 something bucks, but for 23 or whatever it's on sale for now? Sure why not? From what I see on steam, there isn't much in terms of JRPGs besides Final Fantasy, and who wants to play a turn based game? For fans of the genre? Yes, get it, you will enjoy the characters and the world along with figuring out the battle system, but for more casual players, I would wait for a bit more of a price cut.

reviewText: It's a Tales game that still has endearing characters and the fun battle system. While I loved it is flawed, for instance the story is very much by the numbers good vs. evil and there are various aspects of the world that are very vague or could be explained better as well as a few plotholes that I hope that the prequel Tales of Berseria will fix when it comes out. There's also the confusing fusion aspect which ends up requireing extra grinding and farming time to get all the skills you want that could make combat easier. Also the camera in battle is AWFUL as you can't really control it and it becomes very messy and hard to see what's going on. There is also a bit of a glitch where you can accidentally end up playing as a foe but it can easily be fixed by going in and out of the menu and shouldn't affect you too badly. If you're curious about getting into the Tales series but have another system like a 3ds or PS3 I would recommend starting with one of those games but if PC is your only system and can't wait for Berseria to come out then go ahead because the Symphonia port is still reported to be a mess. Otherwise I might wait for Tales of Berseria to come out in 2017.

reviewText:
Game Score: 8.0/10

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Summery:

Tales of Zestiria's new openworld approach and battle system additions does help make the game worthy of celebrating the franchise's 20th anniversary.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

It's amazing that the very first instalment in the Tales franchise Tales of Phantasia got released 20 years ago on the Super Famicom console in Japan. Since then the Tales of Series has had their fair share of great titles, somewhat good games and then bad games that thankfully for company reasons didn't want those games to be released in the West. Whatever the case these games are known for their entertaining skit sequences, great storylines and characters and enjoyable battle systems which are well loved in the hearts of RPG fans alike. Here we are now with the next new instalment with Tales of Zestiria which was announced and eventually released to celebrate 20 years of the long running franchise. It now aims for an open world landscape design, fusions Dragon Ball Z style as well as brining the best ideas from old tales instalments. Sure it's earned a bit of controversy in Japan for the game's handing of the main characters and has earned some rather unfair reviews over in the West. So what does this new Tales instalment fell in the eyes of a long running Tales player like myself? well I am so glad that I get to answer that question.

The setting of Tales of Zestiria takes place in a medieval fantasy world where the land is corrupted by a dark source called malevolence which are caused by the negative emotions caused between the people. Humanity's only chance of purifying the land is the power of the Shepherd and the main character Sorey being your every day standard J-RPG protagonist takes on that sacred duty of becoming a Shepherd and gains the power to fight the hellions. The characters of Tales of Zestiria are very likeable and their character development during the course of the game are great to watch. Sorey is the usual kind of J-RPG protagonist who wants to know about the world as well as exploring the various ruins, he also wants to believe that humans should be able to coexist with spiritual beings known as Seraphim which cannot be seen by the human eyes. Mikleo voiced by Scott Manville who also did Lloyd from Tales of Symphonia also tends to enjoy exploring ruins as much as Sorey but also ends up being the cautious type but their brotherly relationship is a cool sight to behold. Lailah is a pun artist who will use them as a way out of telling out her oath but acts a real support for Sorey. Edna tends to make fun of the party and other people's situations and also loves to insult Mikleo by calling him Meebo which is very funny. Later on in the game there is Dezel who vows revenge for the death of his friend and lastly there are Alisha and Rose. Alisha is a princess of Hyland who takes her role as a knight who will do what she can to help out her kingdom but she holds conflictions between understanding what it takes to keep the peace as a princess as well as upholding her status as a knight. Rose a character who fills Alisha's role for Sorey offers support for him but also acts as a boss for the Sparrowfeathers and a merchant who believes what she thinks is right for Sorey and his friends and her members. The writing is really good and the english dub acting is very strong showing the emotions of each of the characters very well, plus there is also the option for the Japanese audio tracks if the players so desire.

Tales of Zestiria's new gameplay change is that it goes for an openworld exploration which allows you to explore the vast reaches of the world as you see fit, it uses the same field controls like in the Tales of Xillia games so that you'll feel more familiar. The openworld design allows you to explore the environments freely both without the penalty of having tough enemies that can destroy the player instantly (aside from optional boss encounters) and also unlocking new areas at a reasonable pace as you go through the storyline. Compared to Final Fantasy XII which did use the openworld design before this game Tales of Zestiria has a well executed openworld design that makes you feel like an explorer without the game having to punish you for going of the main path which is a great thing. You'll explore grassy field areas, mountains and plenty of cavern and ruin areas which each have treasure and herbs to pick up and returning from Tales of Graces there are hidden discovery points that can be unearthed.

Some areas will have a puzzle to solve which will involve either lighting up pedestal with fire, making your way through areas without being seen using the water, breaking blocks with earth and jumping past gaps using the wind. The earth and wind puzzles are quite good and can be done without any stress but the fire and water puzzles are the worst the game throws at you. The fire puzzles require you to light up a pedestal in order but the twist is that you need to light one of those from a direction that it wants you to light it up from which can be confusing unless you look underneath the pedestal indicating the direction and in what order you need to light them in. The worst puzzles come from the water trial where you need to use the water power to get past the eyes without being noticed, if you happen to get spotted by the eyes you get warped back to the start of the entire dungeon. It doesn't help that sometimes you'll walk into a room and then BAM! the eyes instantly see you without any warning. This actually forces the player to take it slow and examine where the eyes are and then use the water power to make it past it, however even when you do manage to unlock warp points you still end up back at the dungeon entrance if you get spotted which will force you redo some areas which afterwards it just becomes annoying. There was a sequence where I got stuck after defeating a boss fight in Marlind and I had no idea what to do next and it wasn't until I looked online that I found out that you had to burn those dark cloud hellion things using a fire spell that were placed all over the town. I had no idea that I was meant to do so because I didn't think there was possibly any indication at all during any dialogue at all at that point unless I skipped something.

You can take a stop in exploration to visit a town in order to rest up and heal up, purchase equipment and items and also get information from NPC's to your next objective or side quests you know like in other J-RPGs of the last decade or so. Sidequests and shopping have undergone a change, for sidequests they are much easier to track down thanks to a new conversation that you have with the character following you, you can talk to the character following you to have him/her remind you of your current objective or for a side quest's destination. Sidequests will range from fighting optional encounters that are hidden all through each of the maps, collecting gems or just for cutscenes and skits to unlock hidden items. Each of the ingame shops returning the levelling up system from Tales of Xillia only that each store has their own set of items and gears and buying each item increases that shops experience, if at maximum they start doing discount sales and also sell out their best item for sale if you have the gald for it.

reviewText:
I've finished the game and I can say that the story is impressive, but somewhat rushed and gives little emphasis to villains since the story focused more on Sorey alone being a Shepherd and saving the world from spreading the malevolence. However, I will admit that it's immersive in a way, especially when you start sleeping in inns and discover significant places that trigger skits known as Discovery Points. That's where this game redeems itself in terms of skits through character development.

Character Development. Characters are well developed, yet needs more room for improvement as stated above. The good part of this game is that there is a companion that you can talk to, to aid you in doing your side quest (known as Sub Episodes) as well as your main quest (known as Main Episodes) which is a feature I love so I know where I left off in the event I stopped playing for some time. This includes, but not limited to Iris Gems which requires collection to further progress to the story so it would be the borderline of Sub Episodes and Main Episodes since the player doesn't know in the first place that they had to collect Iris Gems. Aside from that, the characters are immersive as well so I do not see that as a problem as a whole, except that, characters needs more emphasis because the party members of Sorey are just supporting him and that's that. Comical relief for the characters as a whole has exceeded my expectations in a Japanese Role-Playing Game.

Equipment System. The equipment fusion system is somewhat confusing because of the learning curve. The learning curve is so high to the point that it will be hard for you to get at first glance. You can do that by activating a skit by sleeping in the inn and by progression. Aside from that, some of the equipments in the shops are expensive from the start, but it will be alleviated as you immerse yourself to the game by encountering more enemies as you play. The summary is this: as you discover more weapons, more properties will be included in the equipment that you find during your playthrough. At the end of the day, discovering possible combinations to further synergize your passive skills to take advantage of the battle will help, especially in dire situations like optional bosses. If you're also planning to increase your stat as you level up, that's another strategy as well if you are planning to focus on a specific stat. Examples are the following: Increasing of Blast Gauge and Increasing of a certain stat as you level up. Some equipments that you obtain provide immunities, and when stacked up, you will be resistant to ailments by half, if not fully resistant. However, Fusion System will break the stack that you created, so it's all about the strategy right there.

Battle System. It's good and it really feels like an action game for me because of how I control my character. The learning curve is easy and as you progress, strategies must be made to further take advantage of your enemy/ies's weaknesses and resistance. Aside from that, taking advantage of the power hits and juggling the enemy/ies is the way to go. This is better with multiplayer because the AI in Zestiria is half-baked and they tend to waste more Blast Gauge than usual in terms of utilising Armatization, this is noticeable in the final parts of the game, especially after tinkering the Strategy menu. But don't get me wrong. The AI is also intelligent and adapts accordingly, this is applicable before the final parts of the game, but it's not as perfect as what you think. Aiming for a no-KO for this game is something you will work hard on, especially when you are under leveled when dealing with high-tier bosses. High-tier bosses are those bosses that roam around the field with the dark smoke at the center of the enemy. Most high-tier bosses will not offer a retry but it's a gamble. However, I believe that issuing AI presets such as Prioritize Defense, Spread Out and Focus Attacks. For the Prioritize Defense, the AI tends to spam restorative and buffs all the way when they could better guard themselves from the enemy/ies's attacks as well as Spreading Out doesn't do its job either because some AIs tend to attack even though the first player ordered the AIs to Spread Out (Taken the consideration of utilizing the Strategy menu). Focusing attacks to the enemy is a lackluster for me, as it's vague whether a) the AI has to focus on the enemy attack or b) the AI has to focus on what the enemy/ies attack will come to further counter-attack the artes of the enemy/ies casted to a specific character. Don't forget the camera issues as well, it will kill your momentum in battle! Battle actions are also a plus to further customize your needs during a battle. I do recommend that you check your battle actions from time to time as you progress the game. You might discover a new battle action that will benefit you.

Quick saves. They are useful especially in emergency situations where Save Points aren't accessible. This is the feature that I am impressed as how Tales implemented it. However, the issue that I find in this game is that, when the player starts loading from the last save data, and the player started to quick save before the boss battle, it will load to the LAST SAVED DATA (where the player saves in the save point) rather than loading from the quick save. The player has to go to menu and will need to load the quick save by themselves.

Of course, some minor but commendable system that needs to be mentioned is that, the encounters are somewhat realistic, such as this one: http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=650984631
But of course, Sorey didn't fall. There was just a major re-positioning of the characters and of the battlefield.

Porting issues. It's somewhat half-baked as well, but tolerable (thanks to the community fix by Kaldaien, I was able to hit 60FPS with this game but it's almost perfect for a port) because Bamco just ported the game in Playstation 3 up to Playstation 4, that can only hit up to 30 FPS. I hope that they will improve on that more in their future games.

Soundtrack. I love the soundtrack of this game. You will love it once you progress through the game.

So far, I recommend this game for those who are planning to buy Tales of Zestiria, however, it's better if it's on sale and includes discounts.

column19: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Story

+ Well-written
+ Several climaxes
- At a certain point it gets a bit stretched
+ sometimes humorous

Sound/Music

+ Soundtrack is overall great
+ Some memorable tracks

Control/Gameplay

++ Great Battle System (Fusionic Chain Linear Motion Battle System); if you've played some of the Tales of games before, you will get into it faster; it's fun; fast-paced
- Battle System is beginner unfriendly (at least it took me a while, but the fun starts, when you grasp it)
~ In battles: the camera makes sometimes weird things but you can get out of it most of the time
+ Control with a controller or with keyboard+mouse is good.
~ World map is too big: You will spend some time running around. Some people like it. I don't. Thank God there are warp points.
+ Multiplayer (only in battles), but...
- ... the camera acts even more funny

Graphics (can't say much since I have to lower resolution etc. so my laptop can run this game)

+ Attacks/Techniques (called Artes) look very cool

Replayability

+ There is a New Game Plus: You can carry over some stuff and activate bonuses

Features/Other (minor) stuff worth mentioning

~ Weapon/Equipment Skill System: Every weapon/equipment can have up to four of 50 skills. Get better results by stacking or order them in a certain way. However, this takes time to do so and requires a little bit of farming. You don't have to rely on it too much on a regular playthrough.
~ Level System: For each level you gain - unlike other JRPG's - your stats increase only a little.
To get stronger you have to rely on good weapon/equipment.
+ Skits: There are a lot of them! And I like them, since they are funny or give more insight etc.
+ Post Game stuff
+ Some Optional stuff like optional bosses etc.
+ 5 Difficulty settings

Archievements

+ Most of them are not too hard to get
+ Made me play the game a second time on a higher difficulty
~ Some Missable archievements
- There is one archievement that relies too much on randomness

Conclusion

For fans of the Tales of series or/and JRPG this is a must-have.
For others I can recommend this game and it's worth picking up.

reviewText: This is my first Tales title from the long running Tales of series. By being new to the title, I had a lot of headaches and frustrations in coping to its over complicated battle system, annoying equipment fusion and skill system, but the innovation is real! Do not be fooled by its colorful graphics and anime style cinematics, because this is not your typical JRPG. I want to see more of the series here on steam, and I can't wait to get my hands on Tales of Berseria.

reviewText:
Game Score: 8.0/10

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Summery:

Tales of Zestiria's new openworld approach and battle system additions does help make the game worthy of celebrating the franchise's 20th anniversary.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

It's amazing that the very first instalment in the Tales franchise Tales of Phantasia got released 20 years ago on the Super Famicom console in Japan. Since then the Tales of Series has had their fair share of great titles, somewhat good games and then bad games that thankfully for company reasons didn't want those games to be released in the West. Whatever the case these games are known for their entertaining skit sequences, great storylines and characters and enjoyable battle systems which are well loved in the hearts of RPG fans alike. Here we are now with the next new instalment with Tales of Zestiria which was announced and eventually released to celebrate 20 years of the long running franchise. It now aims for an open world landscape design, fusions Dragon Ball Z style as well as brining the best ideas from old tales instalments. Sure it's earned a bit of controversy in Japan for the game's handing of the main characters and has earned some rather unfair reviews over in the West. So what does this new Tales instalment fell in the eyes of a long running Tales player like myself? well I am so glad that I get to answer that question.

The setting of Tales of Zestiria takes place in a medieval fantasy world where the land is corrupted by a dark source called malevolence which are caused by the negative emotions caused between the people. Humanity's only chance of purifying the land is the power of the Shepherd and the main character Sorey being your every day standard J-RPG protagonist takes on that sacred duty of becoming a Shepherd and gains the power to fight the hellions. The characters of Tales of Zestiria are very likeable and their character development during the course of the game are great to watch. Sorey is the usual kind of J-RPG protagonist who wants to know about the world as well as exploring the various ruins, he also wants to believe that humans should be able to coexist with spiritual beings known as Seraphim which cannot be seen by the human eyes. Mikleo voiced by Scott Manville who also did Lloyd from Tales of Symphonia also tends to enjoy exploring ruins as much as Sorey but also ends up being the cautious type but their brotherly relationship is a cool sight to behold. Lailah is a pun artist who will use them as a way out of telling out her oath but acts a real support for Sorey. Edna tends to make fun of the party and other people's situations and also loves to insult Mikleo by calling him Meebo which is very funny. Later on in the game there is Dezel who vows revenge for the death of his friend and lastly there are Alisha and Rose. Alisha is a princess of Hyland who takes her role as a knight who will do what she can to help out her kingdom but she holds conflictions between understanding what it takes to keep the peace as a princess as well as upholding her status as a knight. Rose a character who fills Alisha's role for Sorey offers support for him but also acts as a boss for the Sparrowfeathers and a merchant who believes what she thinks is right for Sorey and his friends and her members. The writing is really good and the english dub acting is very strong showing the emotions of each of the characters very well, plus there is also the option for the Japanese audio tracks if the players so desire.

Tales of Zestiria's new gameplay change is that it goes for an openworld exploration which allows you to explore the vast reaches of the world as you see fit, it uses the same field controls like in the Tales of Xillia games so that you'll feel more familiar. The openworld design allows you to explore the environments freely both without the penalty of having tough enemies that can destroy the player instantly (aside from optional boss encounters) and also unlocking new areas at a reasonable pace as you go through the storyline. Compared to Final Fantasy XII which did use the openworld design before this game Tales of Zestiria has a well executed openworld design that makes you feel like an explorer without the game having to punish you for going of the main path which is a great thing. You'll explore grassy field areas, mountains and plenty of cavern and ruin areas which each have treasure and herbs to pick up and returning from Tales of Graces there are hidden discovery points that can be unearthed.

Some areas will have a puzzle to solve which will involve either lighting up pedestal with fire, making your way through areas without being seen using the water, breaking blocks with earth and jumping past gaps using the wind. The earth and wind puzzles are quite good and can be done without any stress but the fire and water puzzles are the worst the game throws at you. The fire puzzles require you to light up a pedestal in order but the twist is that you need to light one of those from a direction that it wants you to light it up from which can be confusing unless you look underneath the pedestal indicating the direction and in what order you need to light them in. The worst puzzles come from the water trial where you need to use the water power to get past the eyes without being noticed, if you happen to get spotted by the eyes you get warped back to the start of the entire dungeon. It doesn't help that sometimes you'll walk into a room and then BAM! the eyes instantly see you without any warning. This actually forces the player to take it slow and examine where the eyes are and then use the water power to make it past it, however even when you do manage to unlock warp points you still end up back at the dungeon entrance if you get spotted which will force you redo some areas which afterwards it just becomes annoying. There was a sequence where I got stuck after defeating a boss fight in Marlind and I had no idea what to do next and it wasn't until I looked online that I found out that you had to burn those dark cloud hellion things using a fire spell that were placed all over the town. I had no idea that I was meant to do so because I didn't think there was possibly any indication at all during any dialogue at all at that point unless I skipped something.

You can take a stop in exploration to visit a town in order to rest up and heal up, purchase equipment and items and also get information from NPC's to your next objective or side quests you know like in other J-RPGs of the last decade or so. Sidequests and shopping have undergone a change, for sidequests they are much easier to track down thanks to a new conversation that you have with the character following you, you can talk to the character following you to have him/her remind you of your current objective or for a side quest's destination. Sidequests will range from fighting optional encounters that are hidden all through each of the maps, collecting gems or just for cutscenes and skits to unlock hidden items. Each of the ingame shops returning the levelling up system from Tales of Xillia only that each store has their own set of items and gears and buying each item increases that shops experience, if at maximum they start doing discount sales and also sell out their best item for sale if you have the gald for it.

reviewText: Ok, Tales of Zestiria, I hardly have any say about this game as I have very few hours as of writing this review and I will likely update it as time goes on, but there are problems. Mainly with explaining mechanics and how you do things, for someone like me who does not own an Xbox controller and is just using a standard USB controller with a PS3 layout the button mappings are a complete mess and some don't work at all. Meanwhile it does not help that in some battles you get a kinda random tutorial and are required to do certain actions and sometimes pressing the button that should do that action does nothing at all. also while this could just be a problem of me not using an Xbox controller but sometimes it does not even tell me what button I should press on the controller to get the desired action and instead tells me what button on the keyboard to press, and during all this, you could be in a said tutorial battle-sequence thing where you can't quicksave nor access your control mappings.(From the little time I used mouse and keyboard, most of this is averted by using them, but who wants to play a JRPG with a keyboard and mouse!?) There is also a lack of settings, when you set your volume, you better be damn pleased with it, because as far as I can tell, there isn't a way to change it, but all that aside, I don't mind just figuring out stuff as I go along as I'll likely end up re-playing this game as time goes on and I get used to the battle mechanics, if you want clear tutorials, this game does not deliver. Speaking of battle mechanics, this game is a cross of Xenoblade Chronicles, and Kingdom Hearts (2 to be exact, there are even drive forms!) Unlike those games though, while this one does have a free roam ability during battles, it does not really offer any tactical advantage besides not being locked to a grid. Meanwhile the actual combat is a mix of KH and Xenoblade, there really is no good way to explain it, but pointing the left control stick or (WSAD respectively) and whatever you have attack set to will do a different attack, meanwhile dodges take up part of your combo, meaning if you dodge once and attack immediately after, you will do the second hit of your combo. On the story side of things, it's pretty normal, kid grows up in some strange circumstance/something that makes him different from the rest some interesting stuff happens in his normally uneventful life, baddies show up, and before you know it, you end up with some mystical power/ legendary role and get tasked with killing what I would presume to be the final boss. Holy ♥♥♥♥, that's one large wall of text, don't worry over time as I learn the game better and have more thoughts I'll format this and make it look nice, but for now, this is my opinon overall. It's worth it for 50% off, I would not have gotten it under any other circumstances, from what I have played it is not worth 40 something bucks, but for 23 or whatever it's on sale for now? Sure why not? From what I see on steam, there isn't much in terms of JRPGs besides Final Fantasy, and who wants to play a turn based game? For fans of the genre? Yes, get it, you will enjoy the characters and the world along with figuring out the battle system, but for more casual players, I would wait for a bit more of a price cut.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: It's a Tales game that still has endearing characters and the fun battle system. While I loved it is flawed, for instance the story is very much by the numbers good vs. evil and there are various aspects of the world that are very vague or could be explained better as well as a few plotholes that I hope that the prequel Tales of Berseria will fix when it comes out. There's also the confusing fusion aspect which ends up requireing extra grinding and farming time to get all the skills you want that could make combat easier. Also the camera in battle is AWFUL as you can't really control it and it becomes very messy and hard to see what's going on. There is also a bit of a glitch where you can accidentally end up playing as a foe but it can easily be fixed by going in and out of the menu and shouldn't affect you too badly. If you're curious about getting into the Tales series but have another system like a 3ds or PS3 I would recommend starting with one of those games but if PC is your only system and can't wait for Berseria to come out then go ahead because the Symphonia port is still reported to be a mess. Otherwise I might wait for Tales of Berseria to come out in 2017.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The most mechanically fleshed out Tales game, but also the weakest in terms of story.

Tales of series hasn't really had a compelling collection of characters or worldbuilding since Abyss and Symphonia. Zestiria doesn't really change that at all, and has it's fair share of cliches and disappointments.

Come for the gameplay, don't bother trying to keep up with story.
