The learning curve is easy and as you progress, strategies must be made to further take advantage of your enemy/ies's weaknesses and resistance. Aside from that, taking advantage of the power hits and juggling the enemy/ies is the way to go. This is better with multiplayer because the AI in Zestiria is half-baked and they tend to waste more Blast Gauge than usual in terms of utilising Armatization, this is noticeable in the final parts of the game, especially after tinkering the Strategy menu. But don't get me wrong. The AI is also intelligent and adapts accordingly, this is applicable before the final parts of the game, but it's not as perfect as what you think. Aiming for a no-KO for this game is something you will work hard on, especially when you are under leveled when dealing with high-tier bosses. High-tier bosses are those bosses that roam around the field with the dark smoke at the center of the enemy. Most high-tier bosses will not offer a retry but it's a gamble. However, I believe that issuing AI presets such as Prioritize Defense, Spread Out and Focus Attacks. For the Prioritize Defense, the AI tends to spam restorative and buffs all the way when they could better guard themselves from the enemy/ies's attacks as well as Spreading Out doesn't do its job either because some AIs tend to attack even though the first player ordered the AIs to Spread Out (Taken the consideration of utilizing the Strategy menu). Focusing attacks to the enemy is a lackluster for me, as it's vague whether a) the AI has to focus on the enemy attack or b) the AI has to focus on what the enemy/ies attack will come to further counter-attack the artes of the enemy/ies casted to a specific character. Don't forget the camera issues as well, it will kill your momentum in battle! Battle actions are also a plus to further customize your needs during a battle. I do recommend that you check your battle actions from time to time as you progress the game. You might discover a new battle action that will benefit you.

Quick saves. They are useful especially in emergency situations where Save Points aren't accessible. This is the feature that I am impressed as how Tales implemented it. However, the issue that I find in this game is that, when the player starts loading from the last save data, and the player started to quick save before the boss battle, it will load to the LAST SAVED DATA (where the player saves in the save point) rather than loading from the quick save. The player has to go to menu and will need to load the quick save by themselves.

Of course, some minor but commendable system that needs to be mentioned is that, the encounters are somewhat realistic, such as this one: http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=650984631
But of course, Sorey didn't fall. There was just a major re-positioning of the characters and of the battlefield.

Porting issues. It's somewhat half-baked as well, but tolerable (thanks to the community fix by Kaldaien, I was able to hit 60FPS with this game but it's almost perfect for a port) because Bamco just ported the game in Playstation 3 up to Playstation 4, that can only hit up to 30 FPS. I hope that they will improve on that more in their future games.

Soundtrack. I love the soundtrack of this game. You will love it once you progress through the game.

So far, I recommend this game for those who are planning to buy Tales of Zestiria, however, it's better if it's on sale and includes discounts.

reviewText:
Here is what you need to know:

+ If you never played a Tales game before, you will still feel at home playing this one. Why? Because when you're in the world of Zestiria; the music, the landscape, and the characters remind you of the RPGs you played growing up. It has a 'classic' aura. Best way I can describe it. Now, though it has this feel - you know it's a 'new' game. Little tell-tale signs of such pop up here an there. The detail you'll see up close, the animations, voice acting, etc etc.

+ Optimization. I'll say this, I've had NO significant trouble with this game. I run it all at max and is fine. Only thing I notice now an again is slight clipping. It's rare, it effects the game not at all. So overall, I think they did a wonderful job on this port.

+ Fashion. I like the way they do the outfit system in this game. It's not TOO simple as to say, give you one slot for a head to toe outfit. You can mix things up and give yourself a unique look.

- Combat. It feels tight. Which, most Tales games do to an extent. This moreso. I wish they'd have given more options to adjust your party's AI.

- Skill tree...kinda. Seems like they could have done this easier. I still haven't really understood what it does when it does it. Not completely. I don't mind things being complex, and this certainly isn't the MOST complex system I've seen. It just feels clunky.

Main buying points to keep in mind.

Unless you plan on waiting 5ish years, this game won't drop below 19.99 IF it ever gets THAT low. If you want this game, get it now or maybe wait for a sale to when it's like 10 dollars off.
IF you like JRPGs, get it - plain an simple. You'll get excited to play it. You'll have that thing where, you can't sleep very well, because you just want to get back on an play.

Now if you like RPGs in general, get it. Same as above.

BUT, if you are the type raised on Western RPGs. You might not be as into this. You won't find this poking through political barriers, or showing breasts. You won't have movie quality graphics. This is more anime style, and like I said - a throwback to older games. Where the world's landscape seems like a more detailed world map.

If you've never played an RPG or JRPG before - this is a decent one to give a go.  I'm enjoying the hell out of it. And I haven't really enjoyed a JRPG in what feels like forever.
So, buy it and enjoy it.

I think I played this for like 6-7 hours on my Ps3 last year(Jap Version). I should say that I LOOOOOOOOOOOVE this port even with the minor tweeks we have to do (that will be fixed soon hopefully). Bad:

reviewText:
Lets be frank here, as this is the first review that I've done in steam.
The only one that seems worthy of doing so actually. This will be partial as I haven't yet finished the game.

Visual: What can I say that doesn't sound as a fan-screaming all over the place? Hahaha, It's beautifully well done, the wide arrange of visual options let you run the game with a good dynamism either on a simple computer or a pseudo-spaceship. Running it on a full graphical option rewards you with excelent definition, lovely colouring and impresive shading in both the characters and the environment. (I still haven't found glitches in any place).
It's impressive that the only LITTLE and I repeat Little" is the walking speed animation of Sorey which seems a bit jumpy and forced compared to the rest of the characters.

Audio: Jeez!
date: I know the tales of saga is famous for the wonderful soundtracks
hoursPlayed: but this one takes the prize! Might sound exaggerated to say it's the best one of the 31 tales until now... But if not
voteText:
it damn well near the top 3.
The fighting music as well as the scene ones are top notch. They are well rounded and you can actually listen to them for hours without even noticing the time you've being doing it.
People have been saying that the Abyss intro song was one of the best around (Karma-Bump of Chicken for the ones interested). But the intro on Zestiria is actually electrifing! (White light-Superfly) I highly praise the selection they did and how good it was merged togethre with the scenes around.

Gameplay: Well
helpfulPercent: here you would expect the game to really shine... And it actually does! The control system is extremely well thought
votesHelpful: the battle options are wide and quite easy to understand
votesTotal: and depth enough to be able to give it time to propperly master it. The Artes / Hidden artes options are well defined
votesFunny: the equipement system is extremely original and rewarding once understood. The originality of leaving behind the mana option exchanging it for an action points bar which is dinamically recovered through the battle is simply exilarating.\nIt is also excelent the way it's thoght the interaction between Seraphs and Humans during the battle. The fusion system as well as the tag-battle option is something they managed to comply without loosing the dynamism of the battle itself. Which we can aslo add that they improved the encounter system so much as to barely feel the in/out of each battle (and we can all agree that it's one of the points that weights down any RPG around).\nThe only little downside on this element that I was able to find
commentsCount: is the limitation on free movement inside the battle which is kinda limitating for veterans on the "Tales of" saga (You need to keep a key pressed to be able to do so).\nI could go on and on with gameplay quirks that makes the game excelent
column16: but I don't want to fall in spoil anyone the surprise of encountering them through the game.\n\nMenus: I decided to separate this category from gameplay due a simple detail. With everything as it is planned out the menus and the options they present do not affect the gameplay at all. They could present to be a bit widespread on a keyboard (If you decide to play the game with one
column17: as if you do You will realize the game is completly playable with either controllers o keyboard). But besides that
column18:
everything is well presented in a way you can actually understand every option avaliable to you.
A little downside on the menu distribution could be the small incapacity to check your own equipment perks in the equipment fusion window.

Story: (I refuse to make points on this until i complete the game on 100%
column19:
but I can say at least that the character progression and the personalities presented are excelent and completly likeable from begining to end)

Making a briefing I can say that this game is another Precious jewel and an excelent addition to anyone's library. SPECIALLY for any "Tales of " fan out there.
Give it a try

reviewText: I am so glad that my friend started talking to me about this game. I had never heard of the 'Tales of' games before and was very curious about it because of how excited he was to play it. After he explained to me what the games were I figured it was worth a try... and I was not disappointed! The game has a very good story and unique, likable characters (two characteristics every RPG should have in my opinion). Also, the battle system is done very well except for the camera angles when fighting in tight spaces. I think the only thing that I wasn't particularly fond of was how the menu was layed out when trying to fuse equipment. Having to switch back and forth between the fusion menu and the skills menu could get annoying when trying to fuse multiple types of equipment for more than one character, but I think that might just be me nitpicking a little bit. Overall this was a great game and I would definitely recommend it to others who want to get into the 'Tales of' games. Now I'm off to play some of the previous games in the series...

reviewText:
*Still in early game as of time of writing*
Tales of Zestiria is thus far proving to be a really good PC JRPG. At the time of launch however it has suffered major bugs but kudos to the Steam forum admin who was taking feedback and giving progress on fixes as well as another user who provided his own fix (the individual even helped me personally which was great) but fortunately now the game is pretty stable. It does only run at 30 fps but I don't mind it and sadly it was developed with 30 in mind so increasing to 60 sounds like it wont happen.

The start of the game isn't very promising, just a warning. It starts out with the same story we have all heard before, hand-holding tutorials, and slow-narrative pacing. Give it time though; the game does improve in all those areas. Combat opens up as you get your party together (most of the games party joins in the first chapter of the game), the narrative and characters become more developed and interesting beyond their trope-like first impressions, and the combat becomes very easy to learn, difficult to master.

As of right now, my biggest complaint has to be equipment and items. They are overly complex to the point where it breaks pacing. Same name items now may have different stats, they can be fused which could make them better or worse, you have a skill sheet too thats tied to equipment that stacks in different ways with each other, etc. I find myself having to stop and take several minutes at a time trying to min-max my equipment trying to figure out what it will mean, what will work, what wont, etc. and it isn't any fun. True, previous games it was boring simple how they were mostly just flat stat upgrades but it was quick and to the point. Here, I'm several hours into the game and I'm still confused how it all works and it's throwing off the pacing where I'm trying to cure a plague from a town only to be stuck wondering why I have a locked skill on my spear because I missed that note on page 13/80 on how equipment works.

So far I would say the game is great dispite the drawbacks. The bugs are mostly squashed with fixes available, and the item system I hate can thankfully be mostly ignored (once I figured that the stats at this point weren't that big a deal it helped my enjoyment immensly) and I'm becoming more invested in the story now. Pretty solid so far, would recommend.

Also on the note of DLC, the game currently has several DLCs in the form of costumes primarily but theres a $19.99 DLC that consists of cheats essentially. Pretty lame but avoidable.

UPDATE: After playing for a while now my opinions haven't changed much but I did start to find myself get into a rhythem and I'm still have fun, so despite the faults it's pretty good overall.

reviewText:
Tales of Zestiria is the latest Tales of game added to the Tales Franchise, which has been running for 20 years now. If you did not know, the Tales of series is extremely popular in Japan and is considered among the best of JRPGS along with Final Fantasy, Dragon Quest and Pokemon. It is an anime RPG series, so if you like Anime and RPG's keep reading. Or if you are generally interested in the title, you can continue reading as well.


I will divide this review into 3 parts: STORY, GAMEPLAY and OVERALL CONCLUSION.



STORY:

*Minor Spoilers ahead*


You follow the story of Sorey, a young ruin fanatic on an adventure with his best friend Mikleo. They stumble upon a young lady knight in booty shorts named Alisha and together they form a bond as they go on more adventures together.

Sorey shortly establishes himself as the Shepard early in the game, the only one who can purify hellions" the monsters you encounter within the game.

As you travel together you meet more new friends; Seraphs
date: beings that are invisible to most humans
recommended: except Sorey and few individuals with the innate talent to sense/interact with them. Each of the ones that join your party are attuned to a different element: Fire
hoursPlayed: Wind
voteText:
Earth and Water.

The main objective for Sorey's quest is to defeat the Lord of Calamity and bring an end to all malevolence brought forth unto the world.

Now with that aside and the overall gist of the plot explained loosely
helpfulPercent: I would like to say the Story is "nothing special". However I do say that
votesHelpful: although it may not be an AMAZING story
votesTotal: it is still a decent and good one
votesFunny:
generally easy to follow and not get lost in. The simplicity of your objectives and how they contribute to your adventure really set a nice steady pace for your journey and there are plenty of extras and sidequests to get lost in that do add more to your experience!

Never once have I felt that the story was moving too slow and it was not going anywhere.

Although the story does follow some cliches
commentsCount: they are cliches I enjoy and like and there are plenty of stuff done differently as well
column16: so the journey doesn't feel empty. An example of a cliche used for the story is "A chosen hero bears the power to save the world". In my opinion
column17: as overused as this plot device is used
column18: it's still a great foundation for a story to start upon.\n\nOne of my favorite parts of playing through the story were the interactions between the main cast
column19: as their personalities clash in times of joy and woe. Truly a wonderful cast is needed to bring out the story to life and I feel they nailed it for the most part. I will criticize on a certain design choice made on a character who later joins you
column20: as SHE (there's your hint) can be annoying sometimes and in my opinion I would value a "certain" other character's presence over her
column21:
however this is unavoidable due to plot reasons.


Overall I would give the story a 7/10.



GAMEPLAY:



On the field
column22: you control Sorey as you move from point A
column23: to point B in a world that is connected by areas. There is no "overworld" so the only way to travel is run to your destination
column24: or quick travel between save points. Quick travel is available early in the game
column25: although it costs money and can't be used all the time due to plot points inhibiting your travel.\n\nThe game is divided into Towns
column26: Dungeons
column27: and Fields.\n\nThe map is easy to use and there are quest markers in case you get lost. Not everything is travel from here to there as there are sidequests to do as you play more
column28: extra dungeons outside the story
column29:
and puzzles which can get to the point of "The Legend of Zelda" difficulty.  I enjoyed the puzzles and they are a nice distraction to keep the game from seeming like your running in a linear line.


The Battle System in Tales of Zestiria is one of the most FUN I've ever had in a Tales of game. If you are not familiar with how the series battle system works
column30: the entire game is played in a real time action based combat system. You can freely move your character on the battlefield and attack when you want. No turns
column31: no waiting
column32: you fight like REAL men.\n\nOne of the biggest improvements to this system is that in past titles
column33: you are put in a pre rendered environment to fight your enemies in
column35: however this has changed. You are now placed immediately into battle upon encountering an enemy on the map
column36: and fight exactly where you were prior to the encounter. You might be fighting on a staircase
column37: there might be a rock you can hide behind
column38: or a wall. It adds a great immersive feeling and depth to the encounter.\n\nYou control one of the party characters and attack via Martial Artes (No. Not really like Kung-fu movies)
column40: with a cast timer) and Hidden Artes (Stronger versions of Martial Artes). The AI will then control 3 other characters.\n\nA Martial Arte is your primary basic attack; fast combo strings that get more stronger and stronger as you chain into it. (Max of 4 chain attacks at the start). They are simply satisfying to watch and use
column41: and you will most likely never get bored of watching your characters chain more and more combos together with your party
column42: as you level up and grow stronger.\n\nSeraphic Artes are for Seraphs only
column43: and cast a spell with timers ranging from very short to long
column44: depending on the level of spell you cast and when you cast it within your combo. For example casting a Seraphic Arte after 3 chains of a Martial Arte Combo will greatly reduce the cast time of a spell
column45: making it almost instant if its a lower level spell. Each element of spell is interesting to use
column47: and spells can also be combo'd into eachother within a 4 linked chain such as Martial Artes
column48: making spells certainly entertaining to use as well.\n\nHidden Artes are just stronger versions of Martial Artes and can only be used with Human characters. They perform similar to Martial Artes except you don't have to be within a certain string of a combo to use them
column49:
unlike Martial Artes.

Now to put the icing on the cake the GREATEST addition I felt that was put into the gameplay was the....

reviewText:
This is the first official Tales series on PC, which is good to know more big JRPG names come to PC. Thank you BanCo to release Tales to PC.

Now about this game. Tales Of Zesteria. This is the pros and cons after just played for few hours.

Pros :
+ Good PC port. It support low/med PC or laptop.
It's good no lagging or crashes until now.

+ Keyboard+Mouse support.
Yes you can play with either Mouse+Keyboard or controller.

+ Japanese or English Voice
Well some people is too lazy to read subtitles, so here it is the option you can choose between japanese or english voice

+ Two Player Support
You can play single player or two players, where your friend control one of the AI party in battle.

+ Features
Many features that make this game quite unique such as hidden artes, sephard artes, equipment skill combination,   customes, and many more that I haven't unlocked yet.

+ Grinding
Monsters will respawn again if you go to the other maps. So yes you can hunt the monster as much as you want I think.

Cons :
- Can't really free run in battle unless you press the  button combined with movemont keys.
Not a big deal, but just feel quite uncomfortable. Tales of Abyss has the best movement for me coz it's quite familiar. *Edit : okay so this can be reversed after you got Free & Free battle action. So it's fix the problem. I don't know it's a feature in game lol

- Suddenly I got that program stop working" error
recommended:
everytime after I quit game from title menu. It's quite funny because I got crash for quiting game? never crash or anything when playing the game tho.. soooo it's kinda.. not.. a.. pro..blem? idk lol

I think that's it for my review now.
Haven't played that far so can't talk about the story and characters yet. But so far
hoursPlayed: I quite enjoyed it. And yes I recommended to try it. :)"

reviewText:
First impression after 9 hours on day 1 (I should reconsider my life):

The port is rather good, it runs flawlessly on my 2 years old laptop on high graphics settings. There are some minor issues like the game not using the dedicated GPU by default and VSync not working unless you enable it in your graphics card's control panel, but I can imagine those being patched in the near future.

The (in-combat) gameplay is fun, somewhat intuitive and depending on the dificulty settings quite challenging (duh). There are some details that I really like, like a have-I-talked-to-you-yet?" icon above NPCs and some about which I wonder why they are even in the game (the so called Treasure Detection triggers at like 3m distance to the chest. Nice.).

Can't say much about the story obviously

reviewText:
First Impression Score: The game is a solid *7* so far. It feels like a good classic JRPG, but has a few glaring issues. As a fan of the tales series I have been enjoying it, but I wouldn't reccomend this game to someone who didn't already enjoy JRPGs. Most people won't get it.

Pros:
-A great overall JRPG experience.
-An interesting story that doesn't try too hard to vere away from traditional fantasy roots.
-Enjoyable characters even if their English translation falls flat.
-Fun and fast combat that you can tailor to how you play.
-The game is well paced, balancing just the right amount of story and combat.
-A lot of options for people who don't care about optimizing their characters while still rewarding number crunchers.

Cons:
-On max settings, the low res textures of the world clashes with how detailed and clear the characters are.
-The English voice acting/translation is absolutely atrocious. Even as some one who prefers english, I set it to japanese for more believeable characters. Whoever did the translation did it forceably to fit the japanese lip sync instead of trying to keep what was originally being said. In most cases what was said in japanese was not even close to the english translation, losing a LOT of what was going on.
-Heavy limitations with draw distance and enemy pop in, even on max settings. The game always looks foggy.
-Due to how utterly complex the battle system is, they constantly feed you explanations for everything, but there is so much jargon that there is far too much to remember. You end up figuring it out easier through trial and error.

I will update as I finish the game. I am enjoying it so far and despite the the pretty glaring flaws the game has, I still think it is worth a purchase if you enjoy JRPGs.

reviewText:
Tales of Zestiria is the latest Tales of game added to the Tales Franchise, which has been running for 20 years now. If you did not know, the Tales of series is extremely popular in Japan and is considered among the best of JRPGS along with Final Fantasy, Dragon Quest and Pokemon. It is an anime RPG series, so if you like Anime and RPG's keep reading. Or if you are generally interested in the title, you can continue reading as well.


I will divide this review into 3 parts: STORY, GAMEPLAY and OVERALL CONCLUSION.



STORY:

*Minor Spoilers ahead*


You follow the story of Sorey, a young ruin fanatic on an adventure with his best friend Mikleo. They stumble upon a young lady knight in booty shorts named Alisha and together they form a bond as they go on more adventures together.

Sorey shortly establishes himself as the Shepard early in the game, the only one who can purify hellions" the monsters you encounter within the game.

As you travel together you meet more new friends; Seraphs
date: beings that are invisible to most humans
recommended: except Sorey and few individuals with the innate talent to sense/interact with them. Each of the ones that join your party are attuned to a different element: Fire
hoursPlayed: Wind
voteText:
Earth and Water.

The main objective for Sorey's quest is to defeat the Lord of Calamity and bring an end to all malevolence brought forth unto the world.

Now with that aside and the overall gist of the plot explained loosely
helpfulPercent: I would like to say the Story is "nothing special". However I do say that
votesHelpful: although it may not be an AMAZING story
votesTotal: it is still a decent and good one
votesFunny:
generally easy to follow and not get lost in. The simplicity of your objectives and how they contribute to your adventure really set a nice steady pace for your journey and there are plenty of extras and sidequests to get lost in that do add more to your experience!

Never once have I felt that the story was moving too slow and it was not going anywhere.

Although the story does follow some cliches
commentsCount: they are cliches I enjoy and like and there are plenty of stuff done differently as well
column16: so the journey doesn't feel empty. An example of a cliche used for the story is "A chosen hero bears the power to save the world". In my opinion
column17: as overused as this plot device is used
column18: it's still a great foundation for a story to start upon.\n\nOne of my favorite parts of playing through the story were the interactions between the main cast
column19: as their personalities clash in times of joy and woe. Truly a wonderful cast is needed to bring out the story to life and I feel they nailed it for the most part. I will criticize on a certain design choice made on a character who later joins you
column20: as SHE (there's your hint) can be annoying sometimes and in my opinion I would value a "certain" other character's presence over her
column21:
however this is unavoidable due to plot reasons.


Overall I would give the story a 7/10.



GAMEPLAY:



On the field
column22: you control Sorey as you move from point A
column23: to point B in a world that is connected by areas. There is no "overworld" so the only way to travel is run to your destination
column24: or quick travel between save points. Quick travel is available early in the game
column25: although it costs money and can't be used all the time due to plot points inhibiting your travel.\n\nThe game is divided into Towns
column26: Dungeons
column27: and Fields.\n\nThe map is easy to use and there are quest markers in case you get lost. Not everything is travel from here to there as there are sidequests to do as you play more
column28: extra dungeons outside the story
column29:
and puzzles which can get to the point of "The Legend of Zelda" difficulty.  I enjoyed the puzzles and they are a nice distraction to keep the game from seeming like your running in a linear line.


The Battle System in Tales of Zestiria is one of the most FUN I've ever had in a Tales of game. If you are not familiar with how the series battle system works
column30: the entire game is played in a real time action based combat system. You can freely move your character on the battlefield and attack when you want. No turns
column31: no waiting
column32: you fight like REAL men.\n\nOne of the biggest improvements to this system is that in past titles
column33: you are put in a pre rendered environment to fight your enemies in
column35: however this has changed. You are now placed immediately into battle upon encountering an enemy on the map
column36: and fight exactly where you were prior to the encounter. You might be fighting on a staircase
column37: there might be a rock you can hide behind
column38: or a wall. It adds a great immersive feeling and depth to the encounter.\n\nYou control one of the party characters and attack via Martial Artes (No. Not really like Kung-fu movies)
column40: with a cast timer) and Hidden Artes (Stronger versions of Martial Artes). The AI will then control 3 other characters.\n\nA Martial Arte is your primary basic attack; fast combo strings that get more stronger and stronger as you chain into it. (Max of 4 chain attacks at the start). They are simply satisfying to watch and use
column41: and you will most likely never get bored of watching your characters chain more and more combos together with your party
column42: as you level up and grow stronger.\n\nSeraphic Artes are for Seraphs only
column43: and cast a spell with timers ranging from very short to long
column44: depending on the level of spell you cast and when you cast it within your combo. For example casting a Seraphic Arte after 3 chains of a Martial Arte Combo will greatly reduce the cast time of a spell
column45: making it almost instant if its a lower level spell. Each element of spell is interesting to use
column47: and spells can also be combo'd into eachother within a 4 linked chain such as Martial Artes
column48: making spells certainly entertaining to use as well.\n\nHidden Artes are just stronger versions of Martial Artes and can only be used with Human characters. They perform similar to Martial Artes except you don't have to be within a certain string of a combo to use them
column49:
unlike Martial Artes.

Now to put the icing on the cake the GREATEST addition I felt that was put into the gameplay was the....

FUSION SYSTEM!

Later on after obtaining the power of the Shepard
column51: which allows you to fuse with Seraphs
column53: and become an entirely different being.\n\nFor example when fused with Lailah
column55: you wield a giant two handed sword with flames that purify evil-- literally!\n\nSorey and the Seraph he fused with stats are merged
column56: making you a one man army. It is simply satisfying on how powerful you feel
column57: when fused and the new Martial/Seraphic Artes you can use will simply blow you away on how spectacular they look when performed.\n\nNow to put even more eye candy to your super form
column58: each line the character now says is heard between two different entitites (Depending on who is fused) and I loved the nostalgic Dragonball Z feeling I got from hearing these.\n\nOverall I would give the Gameplay a 10/10
column59:
fun/fun.

OVERALL CONCLUSION:

Now there is plenty of stuff I can go on and on about this game
column60: but I would like to give the reader a chance to actually play the game themselves and learn what else the game has to offer.\n\nThere are tons of stuff I have not even gone over
column61: which I assure most will enjoy such as "Skits" (Voice acted mini scenes between the party)
column62: and the very complex skill system used via equipment.\n\nAll in all Tales of Zestaria is a great game and has a tremendous amount of depth to overcome the flaws of it cliches
column63: and the Battle System is straight up addicting. The characters are great for the most part
column64: and the newest additions to the franchise are fantastic.\n\nGive the game a try if you like Japanese RPG games
column65: or are interested in it. I can guarantee it is worth your money.\n\nI give the game an overall 8/10."

reviewText:
Having played two star oceans, and a little bit of tales of xilia and symphonia, I was quite excited for this game. I love the JRPG style of gameplay and finding loot, exploring, etc. It took awhile to get used to the controls on the keyboard/mouse. I had to find the right rythym to get off the specific attacks I wanted. And while the gameplay is fun to me, I find most other components of the game to be lacking. I find the story to be acceptable though some claim it is cliche and lackluster, I find it to be a different take on saving the world.

My biggest complaint, is that the main character is supposed to be BIG into dungeon diving and relics. Yet the only thing you will find in the dungeons of this game, are enemies, treasure chests, and corridors. Here is a small example of how barren the dungeons are. After playing 40 or so hours, walking into a dungeon and seeing a torch made me suspicious. I went over to the torch to see if it was something I needed to activate. If a single light source makes me think something is out of place in a dungeon, then you can imagine how barren it is. Literally rooms and corridors. Maybe a decoration bit here or there, but you will always check them because they all scream out of place. All of these dungeons are like this that ive been in except the very first.

The overworld is beautiful and the skyboxes are quite nice. Yet you will see the same enemies throughout the game just with different color schemes which is a con. So although I dont have much Tales experience to say how good this one is in comparison, for being my real first Tales game, I would say I am mostly satisfied. I just hope in the future they take the time to add more detail to their dungeons as it becomes droll very fast.

reviewText:
Thanks Bandai Namco! You put on Steam, my favorite saga!
Tales Of , with the addition of 4K, new filters and support for cards!
Please bring other titles on the tales of, on Steam platform!
Thank you again!
(Below is the Italian full review)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uXjNmeQArm8

In un mondo dilaniato dalla guerra tra due potenti nazioni rivali, assumi il ruolo del Redentore e opponiti all'oscurità per proteggere il mondo dalla malevolenza e riportare armonia tra umani e serafini.
Insieme a Lailah, la Signora del lago che protegge la lama sacra, e al fidato amico Mikleo, i protagonisti scopriranno che una potente minaccia si agita nell'ombra.


Feature:
- Affronta l'epico viaggio di Sorey in un mondo fantasy medievale reso ancora più affascinante dalle sequenze cinematografiche realizzate dal famoso studio di animazione ufotable.

- Viaggia attraverso scenari unici e immensi con l'aiuto dei serafini.

- Padroneggia un sistema di combattimento avanzato, incentrato sulle fusioni tra Sorey e serafini. Ora le scene di battaglia sono perfettamente integrate con l'esplorazione degli ambienti, senza schermate di caricamento o transizioni.

- Supporto alle carte

- Risoluzione (fino a 4k) e filtri in esclusiva PC

- Video in alta risoluzione

- Doppiaggio Inglese/Giapponese

Parere personale:
Grazie Bandai Namco! Hai messo su Steam, la mia saga preferita!
Ovvero Tales Of, con l'aggiunta del 4K, nuovi filtri e supporto alle Carte!
Per piacere portate altri titoli Tales sulla piattaforma Steam!
Vi ringrazio nuovamente!

Il gioco è semplicemente un Tales Of migliorato, sia il gameplay che risulta più veloce senza caricamenti, che tecnicamente!
Il tutto inizia con una Leggenda Narrata... che toccherà a noi viverla!
Tales Of Zestiria è il JRPG per eccezione! Si, io sono un po di parte perché amo la saga, è finalmente posso giocarla senza possedere una console Sony.
Se amate il genere JRPG o la saga, compratelo ad occhi chiusi, che a detta di Bandai Namco ne arriveranno altri!

reviewText: I've been waiting for this game even before the NA release of Xillia 2. What I can say so far is that the game is far more detailed than past Tales games and by far the most innovative entry since Xillia. It has a great setting and recurring story elements here and there that are borrowed from past tales games. The battle system on the other hand is still linear motion although a bit almost like an over the perspective is used for the camera as opposed to how usually you would be able to see all of your characters at once on screen. It'll take a few minutes or so to get used to but it progressively gets more fun. There is a bit of screen tearing which is completely noticable so if this is an issue turn on the in game v-sync and/or v-sync in your gpu control panel. One final thing which may dissapoint some is that there isn't a whole lot of grinding invloved this time around which is usually apperant in past entries although this does keep the story moving rather than slowing down and speeding up in unexpected intervals. I'm a huge tales fan and I've even sold my soul away to Bandai Namco to consistently keep me satisfied with this series so 10/10.

reviewText:
I'm going to start this review off by saying that i liked this game, it was a quality experience. If i were to compare this to many recent RPG's and games in general i'd rate this game above average.

However, I am a long time fan of the Tales games, and comparing this game to some of the best in the series mostly brings dissappointment. The characters are boring and cliche with little to no character development, the story is basic and mostly predictable, albeit plot wise it's better than most, and the difficulty spikes are strange, sudden, and not innovative or skill based whatsoever.  The only thing i will elaborate on is the difficulty issues seeing as how i believe the other two complaints are self explanitory. There are random boss monsters that spawn in each area... they reward you with a lot of experience and rare drops. My problem with these boss monsters is that they are just damage sponges with a ton of insta kill moves, even if you are 20 lvls over them. Beating them is more a matter of luck and insane micro managing of the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ AI teamates . Tales AI has always been kinda bad, so this wasn't a complaint of mine but it is something you should be aware of.

The good parts of this game come from the combat system and the equipment and passive skill system. As expected this game has the best combat of any tales game. It is incredibly fluid, aside from Edna, and each character feels unique and useful. Being the newest this is just an expectation in my opinion. Tales has always had good combat, so It is not a massively amazing improvement and by no means makes up for the negatives, but it is still impressive since this is the first incarnation of a tales game that doesn't have instanced battling and i must say it was a great success. I hope all future Tales games follow this one's lead in that department. The Equipment and skill system is complicated and very touchy but extremely rewarding once understood and utilized. Some complain that the way it's set up crappy equipment stat wise is better than newer stronger equipment because of this skills inherent in them and they interact with the rest of a characters equipment, but i enjoy that. Sure it'd be nice to have stronger equipment although with patience and a bit of grinding you can make it work; but i love how, unlike the difficulty of enemies, the equipment isn't so cut and dry. It's definitely one of my favorite aspects of this game, but i don't think it would translate well to future installments.

Overall i give this game a 7/10 because of bias as a long time fan, but i would highly recommend this people new to the series. This was my Friend's first Tales game and he loved it, and i mostly certainly can't blame him. For long time fans i would also recommend but with a word of warning. I am very glad i preordered this game because i got Tales of Symphonia with it, and without that addition this game wouldn't have been worth $60.

reviewText:
For those knowing the series, Graces is what this title is the closest to, with a very similar fighting system, based on action points that regenerate when not attacking, and a big emphasis on dodges for those wanting to play on higher difficulties.


For those that don't know the series at all, it's a somewhat forgettable story, with most of the meat of the game being the fights.

The fights themselves pit you and your team against groups of monsters, in a closed arena.
You fight using a combination of your attacks and special moves in a real time battle.
It places quite a big emphasis on the player's skill, choosing the right target, using moves that give you an edge, defending and dodging on time to greatly reduce the damage.

I'm not the best at explaining the game, and you might want to check a few videos of the fighting system, to be sure that it's your thing.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
As a big fan of the Tales of... series, my excitement for this game maintained its high ranking throughout the year. Finding out it was going to be on Steam definitely interested me, and I have to say that the inclusion of more platforms proved to be a good decision.

In general, Tales of Zestiria returns to older Tales of... formulas and improves upon the newer battle systems introduced in Tales of Graces, Tales of Xillia, and Tales of Xillia 2. I would honestly say this game contains a good mix of new and old Tales of... games. Tales of Zestiria contains a much more open world than Tales of.. games of late, which was nice to see after the linear world of Graces, Xillia, and Xillia 2. I actually felt like I was exploring vast areas in Zestiria, which really added to the experience. Unfortunately, the world in Tales of Zestiria still feels smaller compared to older Tales of... games, as I don't feel as I'm venturing throughout the world, moreso venturing through a continent. However, this drawback stems from the style the developers are going for, so it's necessarily a system needed to be perfected, rather than a flaw in this particular game.

The battle system in Tales of Zestiria certainly expands on Tales of Graces rather than Tales of Xillia, as evidenced by the lack of TP or another MP-based battle system. In addition, A-Artes and B-Artes return as Martial Artes and Hidden Artes for humans, and Hidden Artes and Seraphic Artes for Seraphim. This makes the battle system seem awfully familiar to Tales of Graces, and really, it's a fun system. In addition, the game allows Seraphim and Humans to combine, creating a stronger playable entity which will completely destroy certain enemies. This game isn't easy unless you master this battle system, so the overpowered entity really assists the difficulty curve. Unfortunately, the camera definitely does not agree with many battles, and while the seamless transition from field to battle is nice, I don't believe the game was ready for that transition until the camera issue was solved.

The overall gameplay system also really expands upon itself, mainly stemming from the fusion system. The fusion system in this game, which allows one to work with different skills, really expands upon the battle system. The goal to becoming stronger in this game lies more in what skills one has, rather than how much attack or defense a certain piece of equipment holds. Until one learns this system, the game can be penalizing on harder difficulties.

There's so much more I could talk about, but really, it all comes down to personal preference. Tales of Zestiria really boils down to whether one wants to have a fun time playing an RPG with a fun action battle system, or not. While I found the story to be entertaining, I can see why many don't care for it, as it's a commonplace Tales of.. game story. However, the characters are enjoyable to watch, the story was fun to watch unfold, and the gameplay was phenomenal. I definitely recommend this game if you enjoyed any other Tales of... game, or if you enjoy real-time battle systems.

reviewText:
I can recomend this game, but it does have a few issues.  Most of the other reviews explain what is great about this game very well.    So in this review I'm going to summerize the major issues.   I feel these issues hurt the game-feel and break immersion.  Hopefully this could help people determine wheather this game is still worth it to them.  My biggest gripes with this game are down to the  environments, animations, gameworld interactivity.

The environments are terribly bland in most areas.  The ground and wall textures are very low resolution most of the time apart from the stone floors of ruins, which have designs and patterns on them.  The character models look great it's just a shame the rest of the world doesn't.  The lack of any foliage and loosely scattered trees was very unexpected coming from a ps4 game.  It would have made the world feel a lot more vibrant even with some more general foliage.

The animations of monsters outside and (sometimes) inside of battle a very abrupt.  Landing a preemtive strike was nearly impossible for me the first 20 hours of the game until I got used to the jerky animations.  If your playing ToZ vanilla at 30 fps, it can be pretty hard to predict enemy movements in battle.  This is an essencial part of the gameplay mechanics since dodging and blocking at the right moment gives you huge benifits in battle.  Plus playing at 30 fps can be really diffcult since you have even less time to react to the very fast enemy attacks.

I enjoyed interacting with the various party members and listening to their mediocre (but punny dialogue).  On the other hand the gameworld itself has very few ways you can interact with it.  Most of the interactable objects throughout the world will be question marks, (???) these are 4 abilities you gain later in the game that help you progress past whatever obstacle was in your way.  Besides talking to people this is your only way to interact with the world.  This system reminds me of a metroidvania style game but very, VERY, poorly done.   Press a direction on the d-pad, and you've solved the puzzle.

Sorry for the little rant, just though it would be important for people to understand some of the issues with this game, although I would recommend it for its combat.

reviewText:
First off, I want to warn you the game may not run on your system if you are on Windows 10. The only way I could get this game to run is with a 3rd party community patch. A game IMHO should never be released in any such form! You have been warned. Go to the discussion board and get the community patch first.

I have trouble reviewing this game because it divides me so much.

I'll start with the positives by saying the game has a fantastic story and set of characters. All characters (annoying or not) are voiced well and likeable. The story is complex and so are the characters and there is a lot to love when the two coming together. This game does a great job of telling a story, as I think an RPG should.

The game has lots of great cut scenes, or mini cut scenes called skits. They do a great job of giving characters thoughts, ideas, and expressions in a fun anime like way. It's kind of a unique system that I've never seen and it just adds a lot I think.

They also have an Anime based on the game in the works, would totally watch.

As great as the story and character are, which really hold the game together, the game has issues.

Even with the community patch, the game does have some graphical issues during combat. Certain effects cause massive graphical slowdown on a GTX 970, which shouldn't happen. Then again the game wouldn't even run for me without a community patch.

The camera in the game does not work exactly as you would expect. It turns super slow. You will adapt mostly, but it's just something that is so weird it's worth mentioning because you will battle it all game.

One thing that was kind of good / bad is you lose a major character like 1/3 of the way through the game. It's not that it really changes anything it's just a really bizarre thing like they started making the game and decided they didn't really want this character to be in the game and then hastily wrote them out. Although the game's director downplays this, it seems almost evident.

The combat system is overly complex, but here is an “easy mode” if you wish to take some of the complexity out of the game. It gets easier the more you play it but sill takes a bit of time before you can really confidently fight “epic” type monsters and survive. The few strong enemies will clean your clock though, and it drives down the fun value.

There are a few times where you will not have clear goals and need to basically wander around until you discover where you are suppose to go. Some better hints would be nice rather than wasting literally hours of my time trying to figure out where to go. Wasting players time should not be considered good. It is a tactic used by bad games to extend their play time. It really kills the pacing of the game.


TLDR;
Overall the game is above average in terms of story, and the characters are great. It's a shame however that the game suffers from poor pacing and other problems that really just make it a mediocre game. The game tries to do too much and stretches out too long for the content included.

I'd say play it with tempered expectations going in, it's an interesting game but it's not going to probably make your “greatest RPGs ever” list.

reviewText:
OVERALL VERDICT

despite camera bugginess and terribad ai programming, tales of zestiria is an enjoyable jrpg experience for casual players and boasts an amazing soundtrack.

PROS
skippable cutscenes

orchestrated music

zaveid's theme

atmosphere and character art design

all swords and umbrellas have their own model assets, so you can watch the cutscenes to see them all



CONS

game has a butt backwards sense of progression: never in this game did i feel like i was getting stronger, rather i felt like the enemies were getting stronger and i had to grind, get better gear, or use cheese stunlock strats to keep up with the increasingly HP spongey enemies.

story is a real hit or miss

equipment fusions and bonus skills are too grindy

some side-quests are actually required for the main quest

objective markers are missing half of the time

battle camera glitches out when battle starts near collision models (walls)

friendly ai does not block, sidestep, nor use freerun to evade

friendly ai does not sidestep to reduce casting time for spells

friendly ai often gets you killed, ie: enemy is casting a spell and the friendly ai runs in and attacks with a hidden arte

weakness and resistance system is gimmicky form of strategy"
date:
as long as you can chain together multiple hits while the enemy is in hitstun/stunlock the game will give a weakened bonus

text tutorials. ffs this doesnt help explain anything while in real time combat.

combat and ai are framerate dependent. the game breaks if you try to unlimit the fps.

FINAL THOUGHTS

if a modding community comes back to adjust some of the combat and equipment mechanics
recommended: this game's lifespan and replayability will definitely increase."

reviewText:
For those knowing the series, Graces is what this title is the closest to, with a very similar fighting system, based on action points that regenerate when not attacking, and a big emphasis on dodges for those wanting to play on higher difficulties.


For those that don't know the series at all, it's a somewhat forgettable story, with most of the meat of the game being the fights.

The fights themselves pit you and your team against groups of monsters, in a closed arena.
You fight using a combination of your attacks and special moves in a real time battle.
It places quite a big emphasis on the player's skill, choosing the right target, using moves that give you an edge, defending and dodging on time to greatly reduce the damage.

I'm not the best at explaining the game, and you might want to check a few videos of the fighting system, to be sure that it's your thing.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
As a big fan of the Tales of... series, my excitement for this game maintained its high ranking throughout the year. Finding out it was going to be on Steam definitely interested me, and I have to say that the inclusion of more platforms proved to be a good decision.

In general, Tales of Zestiria returns to older Tales of... formulas and improves upon the newer battle systems introduced in Tales of Graces, Tales of Xillia, and Tales of Xillia 2. I would honestly say this game contains a good mix of new and old Tales of... games. Tales of Zestiria contains a much more open world than Tales of.. games of late, which was nice to see after the linear world of Graces, Xillia, and Xillia 2. I actually felt like I was exploring vast areas in Zestiria, which really added to the experience. Unfortunately, the world in Tales of Zestiria still feels smaller compared to older Tales of... games, as I don't feel as I'm venturing throughout the world, moreso venturing through a continent. However, this drawback stems from the style the developers are going for, so it's necessarily a system needed to be perfected, rather than a flaw in this particular game.

The battle system in Tales of Zestiria certainly expands on Tales of Graces rather than Tales of Xillia, as evidenced by the lack of TP or another MP-based battle system. In addition, A-Artes and B-Artes return as Martial Artes and Hidden Artes for humans, and Hidden Artes and Seraphic Artes for Seraphim. This makes the battle system seem awfully familiar to Tales of Graces, and really, it's a fun system. In addition, the game allows Seraphim and Humans to combine, creating a stronger playable entity which will completely destroy certain enemies. This game isn't easy unless you master this battle system, so the overpowered entity really assists the difficulty curve. Unfortunately, the camera definitely does not agree with many battles, and while the seamless transition from field to battle is nice, I don't believe the game was ready for that transition until the camera issue was solved.

The overall gameplay system also really expands upon itself, mainly stemming from the fusion system. The fusion system in this game, which allows one to work with different skills, really expands upon the battle system. The goal to becoming stronger in this game lies more in what skills one has, rather than how much attack or defense a certain piece of equipment holds. Until one learns this system, the game can be penalizing on harder difficulties.

There's so much more I could talk about, but really, it all comes down to personal preference. Tales of Zestiria really boils down to whether one wants to have a fun time playing an RPG with a fun action battle system, or not. While I found the story to be entertaining, I can see why many don't care for it, as it's a commonplace Tales of.. game story. However, the characters are enjoyable to watch, the story was fun to watch unfold, and the gameplay was phenomenal. I definitely recommend this game if you enjoyed any other Tales of... game, or if you enjoy real-time battle systems.

reviewText:
I waiting to review this till I at least beat the game one time.  After beating it I can fully review it and how it is without missing out on anything.

The game is perfect, great story, characters, exploration, and even bosses are great.  The side missions are nice, the ruins are each good in their own ways, some people say they look the same.  However to defend that they were built around the same time in the game and they are each connected so yeah.  The gameplay is nice, I wanted to finish it for NG+ mode so I went through on normal.  Monster and boss levels are pretty high even for normal, but overall its a nice experience.  I play to play in higher difficulties on my next play through.

Items are great, there are so many to choose and use for your equipment.  Fusing weapons is new and awesome, it really makes a different to upgrade and keep older weapons.  Other than that there are really no cons to the game, just play it and enjoy the story.  If you have any issues or bugs the community hub has a huge list of fixes for you.  So buy the game if your thinking about it, because its a great game and well worth the money.

SPOILER ALERT (even though i will try to spoil as little as possible)

first impression :

- oh. an unconscious woman in the middle of a ruin. thats unusual. lets help her..wow she looks like a knight, but with a short pants. why not?maybe the king in her kingdom have a leg fetish that oblige all the female knight in his kingdom wear a short pants (later i know that she is a princess that have a high moral standar that dont allow even a panty flash..but with your outfit, do you really think people will listen to you?)
-the battle, instead of 2d, it`s a 3d, and have a few improvement compared to the old tales. but it still have the similar feeling with the old tales system. so i like it

after 1 hours of gameplay :

i think thats all for now. in general, this game is a good. the cliche story is actually make me laugh,like when i imagine the townspeople dying when asking for help to our flirting MC.HAHAHA

reviewText:
Storywise i m done, playwise i just started!


General Feelings
The game isnt perfect and the story is average as it can get. If you play a game for FPS or ONLY for an amazing story you can safely drop this one.
If you, however want to try out an incredible combat system, want to experience likable characters and a good soundtrack you should instantly grab it.


Story
Well you are a normal person who can see Seraphs, invisible humans with elemental powers who are worshiped as goddess due to the lack of people that can see them.
You are more or less dragged into to take the burden of the shepherd. A human who can utilize the power of seraphs to defeat the great evil.

Storywise there is not much to it. However its not so much about i get power and heal/kill all who oppose me" but rather the questions "what will i do if i actually cannot save those who are fallen into evilness" and "What actions will i do and how will it change me".

There are many loose ends and alot isnt well explained (if any information is available at all).
Things supposedly seem very important tp the story but then are not touched again in any way. You mightt get the feeling that the story isnt well presented or written.

It gets the passing mark
date:
but nothing more in this regard.


Graphics
I dont care. Its 30 FPS locked. I dont care. Some do. It looks amazing in my opinion
recommended:
but my standards seems to be to low for some guys out there. So i will not drag this out any further.


Combat System
You have the typical Tales-of action combat system
hoursPlayed:
in which you control one character of your 4-people party in a 3D environment and blast out combo attacks. The other characters are controlled by an AI which can be given general guidelines.
The focus here is similar to Tales of Graces. The main focus is to dodge and wait for opportunities to start combos while the martial artes of humans are layed in a tiered fashion.

There are several types of attacks (calles arte) which cancel each other out the same way as rock
voteText: paper
helpfulPercent: scissors. These types are martial artes
votesHelpful:
hidden artes and seraphic artes.
Furthermore attacks every arte an elemental or type weakness and may inflict a status alignment.

The bosses usually 1-hits any character
votesTotal:
so dodging is a necessity for being successful. Problem arises for AI-controlled which rarlx manage to do so.
Alot micromanagement is necessary in higher difficukties.

Furthermore apart from the already mentioned there is another key mechanic : armetization.
This is a fusion of one of your human characters with a seraph character into a mighty warrior.
This form
votesFunny: despite being powerful
commentsCount: complements the beforementioned rock
column16: paper
column17:
scissor mechanic. While humans can do martial artes and hidden artes and seraph can do martial artes and seraphic artes an artetization can do hidden artes and seraphic artes.

Overal there are many things i didnt touch in my explanation. The overal complexity ranges from overly complex to being button smashing depending on difficulty.


Equipment
The equipment system is rather interesting. Some say its overly complicated. It may be if you restrict yourself to ingame information and dont acknowledge external infos. The really important things are explained but are a bit misleading worded.

Basically each equipment item can only be wield by certain characters. Each equipment has 4 slots of potential skills (attack +4%
column18:
+15% against beast enemies and so on). While the first slot is fixed for all items with this name the other 3 are random and can be manipulated.
Each skill represents a slot on a skill-board. Stacking the same skill or chaining skills vertically or horizontally wield special bonusses. Thats basically it. The thing most people dont get is how the 3 changable slots in each equipment can be manipulated.
This can be achieved by fusing same equipments together. These fusions follow strict rules and are by no means random. Yet you can easily get certain gear with specific skills without understanding one specific rule.

This all may sound complicated but its really only a small (unimportant) part which is confusing about this system.

Overall you can compose your equipment supporting your playing style and there is no "best" equipment (and that are not empty words!)


Other things
Regarding soundtrack : some think its below Tales average
column19:
some think its above Tales average. In my opinion is a below Tales average still an above JRPG average. Especially 2-3 tracks are within of my top 10 list.

Regarding Gradeshop : typical in tales of games is the gradeshop for NewGame+ after defeating the final boss (or continue in post game stuff and then start anew). Depending on the things you did in your playthrough you can purchase bonuses for your next playthrough. Notable things are double/triple experience and double gald (=gold) for fights. There are others too. It only adds to your experience and is overall fun.

Regarding Difficulty : There are initally 4 difficulties. You can unlock 2 harder difficulties by fighting enough battles on the current highest difficulty. The battles are intense on high difficulty and especially regarding boss fights you will get a hard fight. However thats mostly because AI controlled chars are dying to often. But you will die often enough too
column20:
so dont worry! ;)

Regarding Minigames and Quest : There are no minigames.

Regarding Skits : Skits are conversations between characters discussion story events or the cooking tips and other (storywise) trivial things. They are fun to watch and you get a good laugh here and there.

Regarding Customization : Characters can change outfits and get attachments greatly changing the visual appearance in combat
column21: field and ingame events (except the drawn anime cutscenes). Its fun even though i avoided it for the first playthrough. The amount is ok
column22:
however alot of things are hidden behind DLCs.


TL;DR
Its a game with some sort of bland story and visuals. However the combat and interesting equipment system makes up for it (plenty!).
In my opinion its an immersive game and i will probably play it 300+ hours to get great gear and do every thing. Then i will most likly just start anew to experience to game from scratch on highest difficulty without bonuses.

Its literally a long time ago since i bought a game that is so rewarding for me.

So : thumbs up since first minute! Never regreted buying it.


Hoping to see older Tales games (like Vesperia) and the new ones on steam too in the next years."

reviewText:
Just finished the game in ~41 hours.

I love the upbeat atmosphere of the series. Unlike most reviews I do think the characters in Zestiria are just fine. All of them.

The graphics are a little poor, but not to an extent where the experience would suffer Story is pretty good.
It took me a while to get into the game. Overall, I don't like it quite as much as Tales of Xillia 1, but it still is a very good game.

One thing I dislike in the entire genre is everyone thinking they have to come up with new fancy stuff which then leads to battle/equip/crafting/character systems which are way too complicated to be fun. I'd rather have a solid game without this. Zestiria finds a good balance here which is just great.

Except for the crafting/item fusing stuff. This is confusing and annoying as hell. I ended up just fusing whatever I could to make the items stronger. If you try to do it right, considering all the skills and bonus skills you can get out of it, including these you'll get while armazited... well, have fun with that :)

reviewText:
The graphics is very smooth and the game itself can run on my 3+ year old computer that used an integrated graphic card. The game is quite reliable, haven't crash yet but just in case I always use the save portables I find in areas.

The game battle system is very interesting, unlike Final Fantasy, Fairy Fencer or Hyperdimension Neptunia, it does not use battle menu format instead you need to use combo keys aand click your mouse constantly to fight which I feel you're more involved in the battle instead of waiting for the other npc to use their attacks.

The world is sort of open world, quite a lot of places to explore but it tends to get enjoying because your character can only walk most of the time, there is a teleport system but it's not all the time convenient with a click of the map, you actually need find a save portal.

The characters are quite likable with personality not just babbling bimbos trying to be cute. There are males in this game  so it isn't aim towards only male players.

I recommend it for everyone those who are fans of jrpg or final fantasy or neptunia or fairy fancer or someone who wants a solid rpg game. There isn't a huge learning curve, the game will lead you along the way give you tutorial on each need function you gain. I haven't any other Tales of ... games, only Tales of Phantasia so even if you haven't played other Tales of whatever series games you can still get into this game.

reviewText:
This is by far the best game of 2015 I have played so far. Stellar story, deep characters, and a feel that you are playing an anime all in one. The art style is quite nice in my opinion, all the while the combat is deep, and engrossing. Live action combat tied with a combo system like no other. The equipment system is also really well done. Only problem is sometimes in environments the camera can lag a little behind. Last but not least I would play this with a controller. I am using a DS4 which has a slight issue with this game. Sometimes while still connected to the program I use to use it, it will just stop working in game until I plug it in. 3rd party problem most likely the cause. (I believe that even though this is the only game I have had it happen in.)

All in all, I think this game should be a must play for anyone who enjoys RPGs.

P.S. All your Edna belongs to me!

Pros -
Characters
Story
Gameplay
Difficulty (Can go from Hello Kitty Adventure Island to Dark Souls NG+)
Soundtrack
Really I find almost no flaws maybe a few slight bugs here or there but it's far from an Electronic Artholes launch.

Cons -
Camera can sometimes get stuck in goofy positions when in corridors.

Will update upon finish but as it sits this is turning into a classic status for me much like Symphonia did.

reviewText:
First off, I'd like to say this is a tentative recommendation. Buy it only if you are a major jrpg / tales fan or it is on sale.
I'll add that I'm a huge fan, starting like most fans with Symphonia. Anyhow, I'll split this into the good and the bad so you can make your own summary.

The GoodGraphics - Obviously, the graphics are a pretty big step up being the first Tales game to land on a new platform and PC as well. They've clearly done their best to make sure the character models are both pretty and expressive. Personally, I really hope they continue make the model more animated, it really is a nice touch. The environments, especially the greenery tends to look very nice.

Music - Honestly, a lot of the music in the game is fairly non-descript. It serves it's purpose as BGM. However, there are a few key pieces by Go Shiina that completely blow everything else out of the water. Don't know who that is? Doesn't matter - you'll recognize this music the second you hear it. It is used sparingly in some of the most key moments of the game. It is so well done, that it might be the best music I've ever heard in a Jrpg.

Open World - Tales has been building to this for a while. While Xillia came close, it couldn't quite shake the feeling of fields just being corridors between dungeons and towns. Zestiria has the most realized overworld so far. They are truly huge - maybe too big.  Some fields feel ludicrously huge, such that it take quite a while just to cross back from one direction from the other, with not much in between,

BadThe Gameplay - This is the big 'but'. The battle system is obviously derivative of Graces. This isn't a bad thing - Graces is widely regarded as the best combat in the series - but honestly the combat system would've worked fine if it was just that. But one thing ruins it, that is armatization. With armitization, battles are reduced to just button bashing for victory. This is a shame, because the base combat system does have some interesting complexities. I often found myself ignoring it just so I could enjoy a battle more. Unfortunately, this often has the effect of dragging out already long boss fights even longer. Bosses often feel like they have a ludicrously high amount of HP.

The Party - This is likely one to irk RPG fans the most. If you're familiar with the tales system, you normally receive 7 party members in total and can construct any party you want out of them. For this game, you're forced to have two certain characters in your party for the entire game (sans moments where they are removed from your party for story reasons). The other two will likely be determined by the enemies elemental resistances.

The Camera - Zestiria made the bold decision to have battles take place dynamically in your current environment. While a cool idea in practice, this means that the battles are entire optimized for the area. This will result in the camera getting stuck on almost anything. Walls, enemies, even trees. While some attempt has been made to fix it, there's only so much that can be done for it. This will be a perpetual annoyance.

Anime Cutscenes -This is more of a personal thing than anything, but the anime custscenes are sort of a strange holdover from older tales games. In the current state of technology, they simply don't seem necessary any longer. They used to be used to show events that couldn't be performed using the in game engine, but should be perfectly possible now. Honestly, they just seem rather jarring to the flow of the story where they pop in.

Dungeons - I don't have much to say except: jesus christ stop making so many of the dungeons be the same cave with a slightly different layout. It's overused to a ridiculous amount in this game.

You might've noticed there's something I haven't mentioned - The story and the characters. That's because they are very decidedly average. The narrative feels very cheesy in a way I can only compare to Graces. The characters oftentimes only feel like caricatures. Compared to the strong character and story in past Tales games, this is a big let down.

I'd like to make one final point before I end this, that is, the localization. This time, it felt very definitively different.  There were noticably a few 'internet voice actors' included, which may be a positive or negative for you, but I felt was very stiff and lacking, especially as one of them plays a main character. Finally, please stop with the memes. It's terrible. Memes and immersion don't belong in the same sentence.

reviewText: One of the weaker mothership Tales of games in the series, right next to Tales of Symphonia 2. Continuing the tradition of introducing something really cool in its previous mothership title (in this case, Xillia/Xillia 2's dual raid battle system), but choosing to not take any of its successful elements and incorporate new experimental elements that is rather shakey in its introduction. It did take Graces F's/Destiny's unique style shift battle system, but severely limiting its options through poor choices, one of which was initially not displaying a numerical value of SC required to attack with a specific move while in battle. This makes judging the cost of which combos you want to pull off to a rather vague sense of estimation, though this can be helped by just keeping your SC high (admittedly not a good design choice though).\n\nThe premise so far for the initial story is interesting, but only for the first 2 hours of the game. You play as Sorey (or later Rose), the main character and the chosen Shepard who pulls out the sacred sword (AKA Excalibur) and is given the task of purifying the world of yomas and unify the human and seraphim race into cohabitation. There's a few parts of the story here and there that try to emulate a moral choice, something Xillia 2 did well, but only because it had a silent main character. Zestiria's main character has a clear personaility and when picking a choice, it didn't seem to have much impact as the character simply brushes it off with an ugly EH" kind of feeling. Gee
recommended: you're kinda hard to like. The moral choices presented are also pretty weird

reviewText: Great game. I've skipped the past 3 Tales games due to school and well, this was a great refresher to get back into the series. Since this is the 1st tales series on PC, I'm gonna support the devs and buy all the dlc with it just to give them a thumbs up for bringing the game to PC.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
The graphics is very smooth and the game itself can run on my 3+ year old computer that used an integrated graphic card. The game is quite reliable, haven't crash yet but just in case I always use the save portables I find in areas.

The game battle system is very interesting, unlike Final Fantasy, Fairy Fencer or Hyperdimension Neptunia, it does not use battle menu format instead you need to use combo keys aand click your mouse constantly to fight which I feel you're more involved in the battle instead of waiting for the other npc to use their attacks.

The world is sort of open world, quite a lot of places to explore but it tends to get enjoying because your character can only walk most of the time, there is a teleport system but it's not all the time convenient with a click of the map, you actually need find a save portal.

The characters are quite likable with personality not just babbling bimbos trying to be cute. There are males in this game  so it isn't aim towards only male players.

I recommend it for everyone those who are fans of jrpg or final fantasy or neptunia or fairy fancer or someone who wants a solid rpg game. There isn't a huge learning curve, the game will lead you along the way give you tutorial on each need function you gain. I haven't any other Tales of ... games, only Tales of Phantasia so even if you haven't played other Tales of whatever series games you can still get into this game.

reviewText:
This is by far the best game of 2015 I have played so far. Stellar story, deep characters, and a feel that you are playing an anime all in one. The art style is quite nice in my opinion, all the while the combat is deep, and engrossing. Live action combat tied with a combo system like no other. The equipment system is also really well done. Only problem is sometimes in environments the camera can lag a little behind. Last but not least I would play this with a controller. I am using a DS4 which has a slight issue with this game. Sometimes while still connected to the program I use to use it, it will just stop working in game until I plug it in. 3rd party problem most likely the cause. (I believe that even though this is the only game I have had it happen in.)

All in all, I think this game should be a must play for anyone who enjoys RPGs.

P.S. All your Edna belongs to me!

Pros -
Characters
Story
Gameplay
Difficulty (Can go from Hello Kitty Adventure Island to Dark Souls NG+)
Soundtrack
Really I find almost no flaws maybe a few slight bugs here or there but it's far from an Electronic Artholes launch.

Cons -
Camera can sometimes get stuck in goofy positions when in corridors.

Will update upon finish but as it sits this is turning into a classic status for me much like Symphonia did.
